The study is conducted with the approval of the Central Denmark Region Committee of Biomedical Research Ethics and the Danish Health and Medicines Authority.
The study is conducted with the informed consent of the patient.

The study is conducted with a sample size of 40 patients.

Prostate cancer (PCa) is the most common cancer in men. The standard treatment for localized PCa is represented by radical prostatectomy (RP) or radiotherapy (RT). RP is associated with a risk of erectile dysfunction (ED) and urinary incontinence (UI) and RT with a higher risk of developing metastases.
Stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT) is a highly conformal and precise radiotherapy technique that allows to deliver high doses of radiation to the target with a high precision.
The investigators hypothesize that a dose escalation on the dominant intraprostatic lesion (DIL) could improve the biochemical control rate of PCa.
The aim of this study is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a SBRT with focal dose escalation on DIL in patients with localized PCa.
The investigators will enroll 40 patients with localized PCa and a visible DIL on multiparametric magnetic resonance imaging (mpMRI).
Patients will be treated with SBRT 36.25 Gy in 5 sessions of 7.25 Gy to the entire prostate (including seminal vesicles) with a DIL simultaneous integrated focal boost (SIB) up to 50 Gy in 5 sessions, with partial protection of the prostatic urethra and bladder trigone.
The primary endpoint is the biochemical progression-free survival (Phoenix definition). Secondary endpoints are: local control, acute and late toxicity, quality of life.
The investigators will also evaluate the correlation between the DIL volume and the biochemical control rate.

The investigators will conduct a multicenter, randomized, controlled trial involving 130 infants born at less than 30 weeks gestational age. The trial will take place in four Neonatal Intensive Care Units (NICUs) within the Rady Children's/University of California, San Diego network, including Rady Children's Hospital - San Diego, Jacobs Medical Center, Scripps La Jolla (Rady NICU) and Rancho Springs (Rady NICU).

All infants in the treatment group will remain on CPAP until either 32 or 34 weeks CGA, depending on their gestational age at birth. Infants born at 27 6/7 weeks or less will continue on CPAP until at least 34 weeks if they are in the treatment group, whereas infants born between 28 0/7 and 29 6/7 weeks will stay on CPAP until at least 32 weeks if they are in the treatment group. The weaning protocol in the treatment group will incorporate algorithms outlining stability criteria, failure criteria, and algorithms for registered nurses (RN) and respiratory therapists (RTs), including steps to take in such situations.
The primary endpoint is the rate of CPAP/NIS weaning failure. The types of fistulae include colovesical, colovaginal, colotubal, coloenteric, and colocutaneous fistulae[3]. The term Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) refers to the transitional state between normal cognitive changes associated with aging and very early dementia. It is a disorder characterized by impairments in both short-term and long-term memory, but without functional deficits. MCI is considered a precursor to dementia.
Activities of daily living (ADL) rely on a combination of motor, cognitive, and socioemotional skills . Therefore, CI can directly impact independence in ADL, leading to immobility and social isolation .
Gait and balance impairments are common in individuals with dementia, including slower gait speeds, decreased stride length, altered swing time, among others. However, these motor alterations are often overlooked when addressing CI .
A systematic review from 2018 concluded that combining physical training with cognitive training in a functional context can help mitigate some aspects of CI. Therefore, the evidence supports that cognitive intervention should be concurrent with physical exercises rather than separate .
Action Observation Therapy (AOT) involves observing a motor gesture performed by another individual and then imitating the same movement. This technique has been developed as a physical rehabilitation approach that promotes brain plasticity by activating the mirror neuron system .
AOT has been demonstrated to be effective in learning or improving specific motor skills. However, these results have not been corroborated in older patients or those with CI.
The aim of this study is to investigate whether applying AOT in a population with MCI would yield positive results in cognitive status, functionality, ADL, gait, and balance. Furthermore, the study aims to determine whether there are better outcomes when AOT is conducted under the guidance of a therapist or under the direction of MCI-free individuals, compared to self-directed AOT.

Sepsis-associated liver dysfunction (SALD) is a common complication in patients with sepsis, and is associated with high mortality. Early identification of SALD may help clinicians to take preventive measures to reduce its occurrence and improve clinical outcomes. Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) to platelet (PLT) ratio index (APRI) is a simple and inexpensive biomarker for chronic liver disease. However, the role of APRI in predicting SALD in patients with sepsis remains unclear. In this study, we aimed to investigate the predictive value of APRI for the development of SALD in adult patients with sepsis. We retrospectively analyzed the data of 10,000 adult sepsis patients from the Medical Information Mart for Intensive Care IV (MIMIC IV) database. The primary outcome was the occurrence of SALD. The secondary outcomes were 30-day mortality. We first used the MIMIC IV database to assess the correlation between APRI and the occurrence of SALD using association analysis. We then validated these results using our own data. The results showed that elevated initial APRI value was associated with the development of SALD in adult patients with sepsis. Our study suggests that APRI may be a useful biomarker for predicting SALD in patients with sepsis. Further prospective studies are needed to confirm our findings.

It is associated with a range of tissue abnormalities, such as taught muscle bands, trigger points (TPs), and thoracolumbar fascia motion dysfunction, along with poor tissue elasticity. As a result, a composite biomarker for MP related to components of the syndrome is more likely to be plausible biologically, robust, and useful clinically for diagnosis and treatment. Chronic subdural hematoma (cSDH) is a common neurological condition that occurs when blood collects between the brain and the inner skull. It is often seen in elderly patients who have suffered a head injury. The condition can cause a variety of symptoms, including headaches, confusion, and weakness on one side of the body. In some cases, cSDH can lead to permanent brain damage.
The standard treatment for cSDH is surgical removal of the blood clot. However, some patients do not improve after surgery. In fact, some patients get worse. The reason for this is not well understood.
Recently, researchers have discovered a phenomenon called spreading depolarization (SD). SD is a wave of electrical activity that sweeps across the surface of the brain. It is thought to be involved in a number of neurological conditions, including epilepsy and migraines.
Some researchers believe that SD may be responsible for the neurological deficits that occur after cSDH surgery. To test this theory, they are using a technique called electroencephalography (EEG) to look for SD in patients with cSDH. EEG is a non-invasive test that records the electrical activity of the brain.
If SD is found to be responsible for neurological deficits after cSDH surgery, then new treatments can be developed to prevent or treat SD. This could lead to better outcomes for patients with cSDH.

Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the most common cancer in Denmark. The incidence of CRC increases with age, and the majority of patients with CRC are 75 years or older. In this age group, the 5-year survival rate is 60-70%, and the main cause of death is disease recurrence.
The standard treatment of colon cancer is surgical resection of the tumor with a margin of healthy tissue. The surgery is associated with a risk of complications and a reduced functional capacity in the postoperative period. This is especially the case in elderly patients, who often have other age-related diseases.
In the SPARCOL study, we investigate whether the new surgical method Combined Endoscopic Laparoscopic Surgery (CELS) can be an organ-preserving alternative to standard surgery in elderly patients with early colon cancer.
CELS is a hybrid procedure that enables large local excisions of the colon without segmental resection while under general anaesthesia. In our study, CELS refers only to endoscopic assisted laparoscopic resection.
The main surgical advantage in this procedure is the ability to view the colon intra- and extraluminal simultaneously. The laparoscopic approach enables manipulation and mobilization of the colon, while the endoscopic view secures that the resection is complete and not overlapping the ileal valve or creating stenosis.
Compared to the traditional oncological colon resection, the CELS resection is a minimally invasive procedure - organ sparing procedure leading to a reduced surgical stress response.
The aim of the SPARCOL study is to investigate whether CELS can reduce the negative effects of surgery in elderly patients with early colon cancer.
The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial with 1:1 randomization. The study population consists of patients aged 75 years or older with early colon cancer. The primary endpoint is postoperative recovery measured by the Quality of Recovery 15 (QoR-15) questionnaire. Secondary endpoints include postoperative complications, long-term oncological outcomes, and exercise capacity and physical condition.

Cerebral aneurysms are common, with an estimated prevalence of 3-4% in the general population. Rupture of an unruptured aneurysm is associated with high mortality and morbidity. Unruptured aneurysms are often treated with endovascular coiling, which involves placement of metal coils within the aneurysm to promote clot formation. This procedure is typically performed under sedation and local anesthesia. After coiling, patients are admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for close monitoring.
Neurochecks are a standard part of care for patients in the ICU after aneurysm coiling. These are brief neurological examinations performed by nurses or physicians to assess the patient's neurological status. Neurochecks are typically performed every hour. However, there is no evidence that this frequency is necessary. In fact, frequent awakening may disrupt sleep and contribute to delirium, which is common in ICU patients.
The purpose of this study is to compare the impact of hourly neurochecks to every-other-hour neurochecks on sleep in patients after aneurysm coiling. We hypothesize that patients who have neurochecks every-other-hour will have improved sleep quality compared to patients who have hourly neurochecks.
This is a randomized controlled trial. Patients will be randomly assigned to have neurochecks every hour or every-other-hour. Sleep will be assessed using a combination of objective and subjective measures. Objective measures include polysomnography (PSG), which is a test that records brain waves, heart rate, breathing, and eye and leg movements during sleep. Subjective measures include questionnaires that assess sleep quality and daytime sleepiness.
The results of this study will help to determine the optimal frequency of neurochecks in patients after aneurysm coiling. This information could lead to improved sleep quality and reduced delirium in ICU patients.

Patients experiencing problems with their conventional maxillary denture can benefit from implant-retained overdentures (IODs). Several retention systems are available. These retention systems can be roughly divided into bar-retained IODs, in which multiple implants are splinted and the overdenture is attached through retentive clips, and into retention systems using non-splinted solitary attachments. Bar-retained IODs provide good retention, require little maintenance, but are more expensive than solitary attachments. Medium term results of bar-retained IODs are promising with high implant and overdenture survival and low incidence of complications and may be considered the gold standard. Solitary attachments serve as an alternative to bars. These attachments are more economical and are easy to clean by the patient, but wear more easily, which can cause lack of retention. However, replacement of these attachments can often be done chair side. A recent review reported that, when a maxillary IOD is supported by four implants, both types show equal implant survival, overdenture survival and patient satisfaction. However, these conclusions are based on a limited amount of randomized controlled trials. Moreover, most studies reporting on solitary attachments were retrospective. This underlines the need for studies comparing different attachment systems with a longer follow-up. The majority of children with ASBO can be successfully managed nonoperatively with bowel rest, intravenous hydration, and nasogastric (NG) suctioning. However, there is no standardized approach to the management of ASBO. The use of an enteral contrast protocol to assist in the diagnosis and management of ASBO is not well described in the pediatric literature. The investigators conducted a prospective observational study at nine children's hospitals that are members of the Western Pediatric Surgery Research Consortium. The investigators enrolled 314 children 1-20 years diagnosed with an ASBO by an attending pediatric surgeon and underwent a trial of nonoperative management (NOM) on hospital admission. The use of an enteral contrast protocol was at the discretion of the attending surgeon. The investigators found that the use of an enteral contrast protocol was associated with a lower rate of operative intervention (21% vs 36%, p=0.02). The investigators also found that the use of an enteral contrast protocol was associated with a shorter length of stay (p=0.002) and a lower rate of complications (p=0.04). The investigators believe that the use of an enteral contrast protocol can assist in the diagnosis and management of ASBO in children.

The only palliative treatment for respiratory failure is non-invasive ventilation (NIV), which compensates failing respiratory muscles and relieves dyspnea, improves quality of life and increases life expectancy. In ALS patients, the persistence of dyspnea outside of NIV sessions has highlighted the need for therapeutic alternatives in the treatment of persistent dyspnea, including immersive virtual reality (IVR) and auditory distraction through music (music therapy).
The objective of this study is to evaluate the effect of IVR on respiratory discomfort (scale A1 of the Multidimensional Dyspnea Profile (MDP) questionnaire) of patients with ALS at the stage of respiratory failure treated with NIV.

After a period of reflection that the patient deems necessary to make his decision and after having obtained an answer to all his questions, his written consent will be collected by the investigator.
The patient will then be offered a digital therapy session based on immersive virtual reality (IVR) and a music therapy session, 60 minutes apart. The IVR session will be based on medical hypnosis (GAMIDA®) and the music therapy session will be based on the choice of music that the patient wishes. Each session will last 15 minutes. It is of great clinical value and significance to explore effective neuroprotective medications besides reperfusion therapy. Sodium valproate is widely used in clinical practice, and its safety and tolerability has been confirmed. It is mainly used in the treatment of epilepsy, bipolar disorder, neuropathic pain and other diseases. In recent years, a number of preclinical studies have found that valproic acid has a potential neuroprotective effect in acute ischemic brain injury, which can decrease infarct volume, reduce blood-brain barrier damage, and improve neurological function. However, the neuroprotective mechanism of sodium valproate has not been fully revealed, and there is still a lack of clinical studies to clarify the neuroprotective effect of sodium valproate in patients with ischemic stroke. The goal of this study is to test whether sodium valproate could become a new therapeutic approach to improve the functional outcome after ischemic stroke. Introduction: Panoramic radiography is an extra-oral imaging technique and is considered an effective, fast, and relatively inexpensive diagnostic tool to examine dentofacial structures. Various errors such as open lips, shifted or tilted head position, inappropriate exposure parameters, movement of the patients, etc., have been reported for panoramic imaging, which reduce the quality of the images. The low quality of the radiographic images can result in misinterpretation by dentists, eventually leading to incorrect treatment plans. In addition, panoramic imaging errors ultimately can cause the repetition of radiography. Thus, numerous studies have highlighted the necessity of minimising medical and dental diagnostic radiation exposure as much as possible. Patient positional errors have been identified as the most frequent panoramic imaging errors, with some studies suggesting this is the case for nearly 95 percent of reported errors. Thus, it is suggested that all dental radiography staff receive regular training focused on correct positioning techniques and reduction of patient movement. The typical patient positioning errors in panoramic radiography include failure to rest the tongue against the palate, head positioned forward, head positioned backward, head twisted towards the left or right, head tilted to the left or right, the chin too high, the chin too low, a slumped position and inadequate neck extension, not resting the chin on the chin support, failing to use the bite guide, lips opened, patient movement during imaging and not removing the metal objects or prostheses. Among all the positional errors mentioned above, the most common error is the failure to hold the tongue against the palate. Due to the failure of holding the tongue against the palate, the palatoglossal airspace (PGA) appears in panoramic radiographs as a dark radiolucent band under the hard palate and on the apices of the anterior maxillary teeth. This artefact significantly reduces the quality of the panoramic radiograph as it may be difficult or impossible to interpret the desired periapical region for correct diagnosis and treatment planning (for example, making it difficult to interpret cystic lesions in the anterior area of the upper jaw). The discovery of recurrent mutations in the isocitrate dehydrogenase 1 and 2 genes (IDH1/IDH2) and of the 1p19q codeletion has led to a better understanding of the biology of gliomas. IDH mutations and 1p19q codeletion are associated with a better prognosis and a better response to treatment. The IDH mutation is associated with a mutator phenotype and the accumulation of mutations in the tumor DNA. The identification of these mutations and of the 1p19q codeletion is performed on tumor samples obtained during surgery.
Magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) is a non-invasive imaging technique that allows the in vivo study of tumor metabolism. The MRS technique has been used to detect the accumulation of 2-hydroxyglutarate (2-HG) in tumors with IDH1/2 mutations. The concentration of 2-HG measured by MRS is correlated with the number of mutations in the tumor DNA. The MRS technique also allows the detection of cystahionine (CysH) in tumors with 1p19q codeletion.
The objective of this study is to evaluate the interest of MRS in the diagnosis and follow-up of gliomas. The investigators will compare the concentrations of 2-HG and CysH measured by MRS with the IDH mutational status and the 1p19q codeletion derived from ex vivo analyses in tumor tissue samples. The investigators will also evaluate the changes in metabolism during an anti-tumor treatment and their correlation with the changes in tumor volumes and to the clinical response.

Stimulant use disorder (SUD) is a chronic relapsing disorder characterized by compulsive drug use, despite adverse consequences. The inability to delay gratification and impaired future thinking have been implicated in the pathology of SUD. Virtual reality (VR) is a promising tool for enhancing future thinking. The current study will examine the effects of a VR avatar experience on future thinking and drug use in individuals with SUD. Participants will be randomized to a VR avatar experience or a control experience. Both groups will receive a VR park experience, which is an empty park with no avatars. Only the experimental group will have a VR avatar experience, where they will see an avatar resembling themselves in a park setting. The study will be conducted in three phases: (1) a baseline phase, (2) a treatment phase, and (3) a follow-up phase. During the baseline phase, participants will complete a battery of self-report questionnaires and behavioral tasks. During the treatment phase, participants will receive the VR experience. During the follow-up phase, participants will complete the same self-report questionnaires and behavioral tasks as during the baseline phase. The study hypotheses are that the VR avatar experience will increase future self-identification, future time perspective, and preference for delayed rewards, and that these changes will be associated with reduced drug use. The study will provide preliminary data on the efficacy of VR avatar experiences for enhancing future thinking and promoting recovery from SUD.

African-American (AA) mothers have a higher risk for perinatal depression than Caucasian women that is attributable to increased socio-environmental stressors. In addition, AA women have poor healthcare utilization and compliance with psychiatric treatment compared to Caucasian women. An intervention is required to supplement and support the clinical objectives of the mother's depression care without requiring the mother's direct involvement. Fathers are an underutilized resource to reduce the mother's environmental stress and encourage healthy maternal behaviors. The African-American Social Support Effectiveness Treatment- Partners alleviating Perinatal Depression (ASSET-PPD) protocol will target the fathers' support of the mothers' mental health treatment and their active engagement in the family to reduce maternal stress. The ASSET-PPD intervention will be designed to have 4 active modules that address key factors to reduce maternal stress during the prenatal period and 2 postpartum review sessions. The modules will be individual sessions constructed to provide training, information, and behavioral assignments to increase fathers': 1) prenatal and postpartum family involvement; 2) mental health psychoeducation; 3) interparental communication and relationship skills; and 4) balanced division of family tasks. ASSET-PPD will be evaluated in a pilot Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT) with 50 cohabiting or non-cohabiting fathers and AA mothers who will be randomized into the ASSET-PPD intervention or the comparator group. Fathers only will participate in the intervention, and mothers and fathers will complete measures of mental health and parental experiences. Maternal depressive symptoms will be assessed as a primary outcome, and breastfeeding and parent-infant interactions will be assessed as secondary outcomes.

In individuals with type 1 diabetes, adjusting insulin doses to accommodate the ever-changing conditions of daily life is crucial for achieving satisfactory metabolic control. To address this challenge, researchers have developed an Automated Insulin Delivery (AID) system, commonly known as an artificial pancreas. This system comprises of an insulin pump, a continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) sensor, and a sophisticated control algorithm. The algorithm uses CGM data to calculate the insulin dose required to maintain good glycemic control, and it automatically commands the insulin infusion. However, artificial pancreas systems can experience malfunctions, some of which are highly risky. The most dangerous malfunctions include insulin pump failures and infusion set occlusions, which lead to prolonged interruptions in insulin delivery. This exposes the patient to the risk of hyperglycemia and, even more dangerously, ketoacidosis, a severe complication that can result in hospitalization and, in severe cases, death. Unfortunately, patients do not always notice these issues in a timely manner. This study aims to test new algorithms for detecting pump/infusion set malfunctions that result in reduced or interrupted insulin delivery. This data is obtained from a download form the patient's artificial pancreas. The one-month session is designed to gather a substantial amount of patient-specific data to enable the algorithms to learn how insulin and meals impact the patient's glycemia as recorded by the CGM sensor. During this phase, the patient continues to use their artificial pancreas in their daily life. Phase 2: Induction of Hyperglycemia The second phase involves the patient visiting the clinic, where, according to a specific protocol and a defined schedule, insulin infusion is temporarily suspended to simulate a pump malfunction. Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that acts by increasing the concentration of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. Sugammadex is a modified cyclodextrin that binds to rocuronium and is eliminated as a rocuronium-sugammadex complex. Neuromuscular blockers are reversed by neostigmine and sugammadex in a dose-dependent manner. The time to first available neurologic assessment after intubation is unknown in critically ill patients who are reversed with neostigmine or sugammadex. This is a prospective, randomized, controlled, triple-masked study. Patients who agree to participate in the study will be randomized to the sugammadex group, neostigmine group, or control group. Important psychological problems can be experienced after sports injuries such as anterior cruciate ligament (ACL), these delay physical recovery, affect the quality of rehabilitation, and eventually cause problems or re-injuries in the process of returning to sports. The most important of these problems are re-injury anxiety, rehabilitation adherence, rehabilitation self-efficacy problems, and kinesiophobia. Although some interventions have been proposed for the solution of these problems, a structured intervention approach has not been put forward yet. With this research project, our aim is to examine the effectiveness of the Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) protocol (CBT+VR) enriched with the contribution of virtual reality (VR), which the investigators prepared to intervene in psychological problems that arise after ACL operation. If the CBT+VR protocol is effective, it can be used to increase the quality of physical rehabilitation and therefore to ensure that the perceptions of athletes regarding their psychological outcomes about their return to sport are positive. CBT+VR protocol will be tested, and if it is found effective, it will make a significant contribution to both the literature and practice. The main peculiarity of this study is that a holistic protocol including virtual intervention will be developed for the solution of psychological problems encountered in the rehabilitation process of sports injuries for the first time.

The investigators have developed a patient-level clinical decision support tool to guide optimal treatment frequency. This tool-the Physical Therapy Frequency Clinical Decision Support Tool, or PT-PENCIL-is based on a statistical model that predicts discharge home relative to the frequency of physical therapist treatment. The primary goals of this study are to assess the development and implementation strategy for the PT-PENCIL and analyze its effect on improving the proportion of patients who discharge home. The PT-PENCIL will include two solutions integrated into the electronic health record (Epic). For both, Epic will use the underlying statistical model to identify patients for whom daily physical therapist treatment may be indicated in order to facilitate a discharge to home. For such patients, an Epic best practice advisory (BPA) alert will appear on the screen, which will prompt therapists to consider a visit on the next day. The second Epic-integrated solution is an indicator column on the patient lists maintained by therapists, which will identify patients who would benefit from daily PT (a green dot), those who would not (a red dot), and those for whom the PT-PENCIL did not run in Epic (a yellow dot). PT-PENCIL will be implemented into clinical care by means of a pilot hybrid type 2 design, informed by the PRISM (Practical, Robust Implementation and Sustainability Model) and RE-AIM (reach, effectiveness, adoption, implementation, and maintenance) frameworks.

Pulse oximetry is a non-invasive, reliable, and accurate method of measuring oxygen saturation in arterial blood. It is used in a variety of clinical settings, including anesthesia, intensive care, and home healthcare. However, the accuracy of pulse oximetry is dependent on the wavelengths of light used to detect oxygenated and deoxygenated hemoglobin. The current pulse oximeters are calibrated for Caucasian skin tones, and thus are less accurate in patients with darker skin tones. This is due to the fact that melanin, the pigment that gives skin its color, absorbs light at the same wavelengths as hemoglobin. As a result, the signal-to-noise ratio is decreased, leading to less accurate readings.
The investigators have developed a novel pulse oximeter that uses three wavelengths of light to detect oxygen saturation. The device also includes a melanin sensor that measures the amount of melanin in the skin. The device uses this information to adjust the calibration of the pulse oximeter, allowing for more accurate readings in patients with darker skin tones.
The investigators aim to evaluate the accuracy of the novel pulse oximeter in patients with darker skin tones. The investigators will also assess the comfort and safety of the device.
The investigators hypothesize that the novel pulse oximeter will be more accurate in patients with darker skin tones. The investigators also hypothesize that the device will be well-tolerated and safe for use.

Heart failure is a common condition with a high prevalence and a poor prognosis. The main symptoms of heart failure are fatigue and dyspnea, which are caused by a reduced cardiac output and an increased peripheral vascular resistance. In addition, patients with heart failure often have symptoms of volume overload, such as edema and dyspnea. Volume overload is caused by an imbalance between fluid intake and fluid excretion. In heart failure patients, the kidneys retain sodium and water, leading to an expansion of the extracellular fluid volume. The increased extracellular fluid volume causes an increase in venous pressure and a reduction in cardiac output. In addition, volume overload is associated with a reduced sensitivity to vasodilators and an increased peripheral vascular resistance.
The endothelial glycocalyx (GCX) is a gel-like structure that lines the inner wall of blood vessels. The GCX is composed of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs), proteoglycans, and glycoproteins. The GCX plays an important role in maintaining vascular homeostasis. The GCX is responsible for the selective permeability of the vascular endothelium and regulates the interaction between blood components and the vascular wall. Pegylated interferon-α (Peg-IFNα) can achieve sustained hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) loss in a small proportion of patients with CHB. However, the side effects of Peg-IFNα limit its application in clinical practice.
Programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1) is a negative regulatory factor of the immune system. Anti-PD-1 antibody can enhance T cell response and has been approved for the treatment of various cancers.

One group will receive NAs combined with anti-PD-1 antibody and Peg-IFNα, and the other group will receive NAs combined with Peg-IFNα. The primary endpoint is the proportion of patients with HBsAg loss at week 24. The secondary endpoints include the proportion of patients with HBsAg loss at week 48, the proportion of patients with HBsAg loss at week 24 after the end of treatment, the proportion of patients with ALT normalization, the proportion of patients with HBV DNA < 10 copies/mL, the proportion of patients with HBeAg seroconversion, the proportion of patients with adverse events, and the changes of HBsAg level, HBV DNA level, and ALT level.

Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) is the most common compression neuropathy. CTS results from the compression of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel. The main symptoms include pain and other unpleasant sensations in hand and wrist. In more advanced stage, weakness and wasting of the thenar and other muscles innervated by median nerve occurs, which may lead to permanent impairment of manual performance. Nerve conduction studies (NCS) remain the method of choice in diagnosing CTS. However ultrasonography (US) is increasingly used along with or instead of NCS. Most frequently, the increase of the cross-sectional area of the median nerve at the inlet to the carpal tunnel is regarded as the marker of CTS. A number of other measurements such as median nerve mobility, volar bulging of flexor retinaculum and others were also studied to increase diagnostic sensitivity and specificity. In this study the investigators aim to assess the utility of measurements made at the point of the maximal stenosis of the median nerve in the tunnel to diagnose CTS. So far, there were only few studies, which visualized the maximal nerve stenosis, which is the essential pathological feature of CTS. In general, the group of patients with CTS and controls will undergo NCS of symptomatic median and ipsilateral ulnar nerves and US of the symptomatic median nerve with measurements of the cross-sectional area, diameter and echogenicity at various points, including the point of the maximal stenosis. The location of the maximal stenosis with respect to external (distal crease) and internal (wrist and hand bones and thenar musculature) will also be evaluated. Subjects will also be asked to fill out the Boston Carpal Tunnel Questionnaire (BCTQ) and a demographic questionnaire. US measurements will be compared between patients and healthy volunteers. US measurements will be correlated among patients with clinical severity of CTS, reflected by the score in BCTQ and with the grade of electrophysiological severity as introduced by Padua et al. [1].

Infertility is a common problem in couples who desire to have children. In approximately 50% of infertile couples, the male partner is the sole or main cause of infertility. In these men, the sperm cells have abnormalities in their shape, movement, or genetic material. These abnormalities can reduce the chance of pregnancy. Intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) is a common treatment for infertility caused by sperm abnormalities. In ICSI, a single sperm is injected directly into an egg to help the egg to fertilize. However, even with ICSI, the chance of pregnancy may be lower if the sperm has a high percentage of genetic abnormalities.
One way to improve the chance of pregnancy in these cases is to use sperm that has been separated to remove sperm with genetic abnormalities. This can be done using a technique called microfluidic sperm separation. In this technique, sperm is mixed with a liquid and passed through a small channel. The sperm with the best movement and shape are able to swim through the channel, while the sperm with abnormalities are trapped. The sperm that comes out of the other side of the channel is then used for ICSI.
Another way to obtain sperm for ICSI is through a procedure called testicular sperm extraction (TESA). In this procedure, sperm is directly extracted from the testicle. TESA is often used when there is a low sperm count or no sperm in the semen.
In this study, the investigators will compare the outcomes of ICSI using sperm that has been separated using microfluidic sperm separation (Zymot) with the outcomes of ICSI using sperm obtained through TESA in couples where the sperm has a high percentage of genetic abnormalities. The investigators will also compare the cost and the number of eggs that need to be injected in each case. The investigators hope that this study will help to improve the chance of pregnancy in couples where the sperm has a high percentage of genetic abnormalities.

Routine patient-reported outcome (PRO) monitoring is an evidence-based practice that improves patient outcomes. PROs are a powerful tool to bridge the gap between patients and clinical teams, amplifying the patient experience and improving communication between patients and clinicians. A seminal clinical trial was conducted in which weekly PRO symptom assessments with care team alerts led to reduced care utilization, improved quality of life, and lengthened overall survival among patients receiving active treatment for advanced solid tumors. Subsequent randomized trials have corroborated the quality of life and survival advantages of PRO monitoring in other cancer populations and practice settings. Real-world adherence to PRO monitoring is lower than in seminal clinical trials, with potential racial/ethnic disparities. Multilevel barriers to PRO implementation exist at the patient, clinician, practice, and system levels. While patient adherence to PRO monitoring in seminal trials ranged from 70 to 90 percent, real-world adherence is much lower and more variable. Moreover, compared to non-Hispanic White patients, Black and Hispanic patients were 9% and 4% less likely to complete PRO questionnaires, respectively, but more likely to report more severe symptoms. These results highlight that historically marginalized subgroups may benefit less from current methods of PRO administration, potentially reinforcing existing disparities in symptom management if not remediated. This will be the first study to apply behavioral economic strategies to align clinicians and patients in achieving sustained patient-level PRO adherence, and addresses limitations of current PRO approaches. Current approaches to PRO collection are limited by: (1) suboptimal clinician engagement, (2) encounter-based assessments which preclude longitudinal monitoring of PROs outside of the clinic, and (3) insufficient automated effectors actively linking reported symptoms with clinical response. This proposal addresses these limitations by employing behavioral strategies directly targeting clinician engagement, utilizing novel electronic remote monitoring methods to maximize real-time PRO capture, and linking these with pathway-driven automated effectors.

However, there is limited evidence from LMICs that supports the clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of delivering these psychosocial interventions to individuals with FEP. We aim to determine the clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of Culturally adapted Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CaCBT) and Culturally adapted Family Intervention (CulFI) compared to TAU in reducing overall symptoms of psychosis in individuals with FEP in Pakistan. The study will include 390 participants with FEP from psychiatric units of hospitals in ten centres (i.e. Karachi, Lahore, Rawalpindi, Hyderabad, Qambar Shahdakot, Shaheed Benazirabad, Sukkur, Peshawar, Quetta and Multan). Consented participants meeting eligibility criteria will be randomised in a 1:1:1 allocation to CaCBT + TAU, CulFI + TAU or TAU alone. Participants in CaCBT intervention group will receive 12-weekly one-to-one sessions. Participants in CulFI group will receive 10-weekly one-to-one sessions. Each CaCBT and CulFI session will last for approximately 1 hour. Sessions will be delivered by trained psychologists who will receive regular weekly supervision to maintain fidelity. Assessments will be carried out at baseline, months 3, 6, and 12 by trained, blinded assessors. . Process evaluation will help to build the implementation knowledge base for proposed interventions across study settings. We will conduct economic evaluations (i.e., the cost-effectiveness and cost-utility analyses) of the CaCBT and CulFI interventions, as add-on to TAU.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a public health disaster, with over 1 million deaths in the US alone. Vaccination is the most effective strategy to prevent the spread of COVID-19 and its variants, but vaccine uptake in the US has lagged behind other countries. A recent survey found that 20% of unvaccinated Americans report that they will never get the vaccine. Misinformation and mistrust in science and government are key drivers of vaccine hesitancy. Individuals with anxiety and depression are particularly vulnerable to misinformation and are less likely to be vaccinated.
The investigators propose to test the effectiveness of two brief digital interventions to increase vaccine uptake among individuals with anxiety or depressive symptoms. The investigators will use a nationally-representative community cohort to identify individuals who are undervaccinated and have symptoms of anxiety or depression. The investigators will then randomly assign participants to one of three interventions: 1) an attitudinal inoculation intervention; 2), a CBT-informed intervention; or 3) a conventional public health messaging intervention. The investigators will examine the outcome of COVID-19 vaccination at 4 weeks post-intervention, conducting intent-to-treat comparisons between arms.
The investigators hypothesize that both interventions will be more effective than conventional public health messaging at increasing vaccine uptake among individuals with anxiety or depressive symptoms. The investigators also hypothesize that the attitudinal inoculation intervention will be more effective than the CBT-informed intervention.

The purpose of this study was to examine the effects of binaural beat music (BBM) on sleep quality, heart rate variability (HRV), and depression in older people with poor sleep quality in a long-term care institution. This study was a randomized controlled trial. The participants were 65 years old and older who stayed in a long-term care institution and had poor sleep quality. The participants were randomly assigned to the Binaural beat music group (BBM group) or the control group. The BBM group listened to 15 minutes of Taiwanese Hokkien oldies (familiar music, can be selected by participant) with BBM embedded three times a week for two weeks (total of 12 times). The control group listened to 15 minutes of Taiwanese Hokkien oldies (familiar music, can be selected by participant) without BBM embedded three times a week for two weeks (total of 12 times). The Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), HRV analyzer, and Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS) were used to assess sleep quality, HRV, and depression, respectively. The PSQI was administered twice, before and after the intervention. The GDS and HRV analyzer were administered once, after the intervention. The independent t-test and paired t-test were used to analyze the data. The results showed that the BBM group had significantly better sleep quality, HRV, and lower depression scores than the control group. The results of this study suggested that BBM could be used as a non-pharmacological intervention to improve sleep quality, HRV, and depression in older people with poor sleep quality in a long-term care institution.

Patients are usually followed up in clinic for 5 years after treatment, but the majority will not have their cancer return during this time. This can be a worrying experience for patients and can place a burden on the health service.
The investigators have developed a personalised follow-up pathway for patients who have completed treatment for HNC. Patients are invited to a clinic appointment 2 years after treatment, where they will have a clinical review and be offered a CT scan. Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the commonest cardiac arrhythmia, affecting over 1 million people in the UK. It is associated with a 50% increased risk of stroke, heart failure and death. The mechanisms underlying the development of AF are poorly understood, but it is known that the left atrial undergoes structural and electrical remodelling, which is thought to be a driver of AF.
The left atrial appendage (LAA) is a thin pouch of muscle that protrudes from the left atrium. It is thought to be a key driver of AF, and in patients undergoing cardiac surgery, surgical exclusion of the LAA is associated with a reduction in stroke.
During lung resections for malignancies, the pulmonary veins (PVs) and surrounding portion of the left atrium are also removed. These operations therefore provide tissue which is known to be of great importance in promoting and sustaining AF, but which is normally discarded.
In the current study proposal, we will obtain this tissue and analyse it histologically. In the first instance, as a pilot study of up to 10 patients to assess the feasibility of such an analysis. This sample size is informed by our previous basic science studies of cardiac and lung fibrosis and will inform the design of a future full study. We aim to obtain samples from patients in sinus rhythm (thoracic surgical patients) and varying durations of AF (all surgical cases) to encompass tissues with different degrees of fibrosis.

The aim of this study is to compare the effect of standard diuretic therapy with furosemide infusion and matched dehydration with the RenalGuard System to standard diuretic therapy alone in patients with ADHF and overt fluid overload.

Therefore, at present, intravenous anesthesia is often used in clinical practice to reduce discomfort, and intravenous propofol combined with fentanyl is the most widely used in clinical practice. Radiation-induced intestinal injury (RAII) is a common complication of radiotherapy for pelvic malignancies. The incidence of RAII is closely related to the radiation dose and the volume of small bowel and rectum receiving the radiation dose. With the development of radiotherapy technology, the dose of radiotherapy has been increased, and the incidence of RAII has also increased. RAII can be divided into acute phase and chronic phase. The acute phase of RAII occurs within 90 days after radiotherapy, and the chronic phase occurs after 90 days. The acute phase of RAII is usually self-limited and can be relieved by symptomatic treatment. However, the chronic phase of RAII can be progressive and even life-threatening. The chronic phase of RAII is mainly manifested as radiation-induced intestinal fibrosis, radiation-induced intestinal stricture, radiation-induced intestinal fistula, and radiation-induced intestinal bleeding. The chronic phase of RAII can lead to malnutrition, diarrhea, and even intestinal obstruction, which seriously affects the quality of life of patients and increases the medical burden. Therefore, it is very important to predict the chronicization of RAII.
The pathogenesis of RAII is closely related to the immune response. Studies have shown that the expression of immune factors in the intestinal mucosa can predict the occurrence of RAII. However, there are few studies on the prediction of the chronicization of RAII. In this study, the investigators will collect the clinical data and intestinal tissue samples of patients with RAII, and detect the expression of immune factors in the intestinal tissue samples. The investigators will use machine learning and other methods to establish a prediction model for the chronicization of RAII. The investigators will also verify the predictive efficacy of the prediction model in a prospective cohort. The investigators expect that this study can provide a new method for the early prediction of the chronicization of RAII, and provide a basis for the prevention and treatment of the chronic phase of RAII.

The most common surgical procedure for the correction of apical POP is sacrocolpopexy, which involves the suspension of the vaginal apex to the sacral promontory using mesh. However, this procedure requires an abdominal incision and may be associated with complications such as mesh erosion. Therefore, alternative procedures have been developed, such as lateral suspension, pectopexy, and sacrospinous ligament fixation. These procedures are less invasive and may be associated with fewer complications. However, the effect of these procedures on the vaginal axis is not well understood. The aim of this study is to compare the vaginal axis in patients undergoing apical POP surgery, whether they have undergone hysterectomy or not. The investigation is designed to test the null hypothesis by means of a comparative analysis of preoperative and postoperative Magnetic Resonance Imaging images capturing the vaginal axis. This examination will be conducted on patients slated to receive lateral mesh suspension, pectopexy, and sacrospinous ligament fixation procedures for the correction of apical POP.

This research is centered on the comparative effectiveness of Gong's and Kaltenborn's mobilization techniques in the treatment of Adhesive Capsulitis, addressing a significant void in current literature. Prior studies have individually showcased the efficacy of both techniques in enhancing pain relief, expanding range of motion, and improving functional outcomes among patients. However, a direct comparative analysis between Gong's and Kaltenborn's mobilization is conspicuously absent, prompting this study to unveil potential distinctions in their impact on shoulder pain, range of motion, and functional mobility.
The research design involves the random allocation of participants into two groups: Group A, receiving Gong's mobilization, and Group B, undergoing Kaltenborn's mobilization. Data collection will be performed by an assessor at specified intervals, allowing for a comprehensive understanding of the interventions' effects over time.
Ultimately, this research aspires to contribute evidence-based insights into the relative effectiveness of Gong's and Kaltenborn's mobilization techniques, aiding clinicians in making informed decisions for optimal patient outcomes in the context of Adhesive Capsulitis.

Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the fifth most common cancer and the second leading cause of cancer death worldwide. Radiotherapy (RT) is an important treatment option for HCC. However, the residual tumors and early recurrence/metastasis after RT compromise the patient survival. Timely detecting residual/recurrence/metastasis and the clonality is required to implement salvage therapies properly. The major unmet needs of radiotherapy to HCC are the difficulties in early evaluating response by images and timely detection of intrahepatic recurrence and extrahepatic metastasis. Thus, an accurate and personalized biomarker for response prediction and disease monitoring is demanded. Cell-free tumor-specific DNA (ctDNA) has garnered attention as a promising biomarker in cancer patients. However, in HCC, the detection rate is low (9-21.2%), mainly due to the limited prevalence of traditional somatic mutations and the difficult separation of ctDNA fragments from normal cells. Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most common and aggressive type of brain tumour. After surgery, a key step in treatment is radiotherapy. The standard clinical target volume (CTV) for radiotherapy treatment planning includes all tumour cells remaining after surgery. Currently, the GTV is expanded in all directions with 1.5cm into visibly healthy tissue to account for microscale tumour invasion. This standard CTV therefore also contains healthy tissue that should not be receiving radiation, causing side effects of treatment, hereby reducing quality of life for patients. Generating a physiological CTV for radiotherapy treatment planning for patients with brain tumours is essential for reducing side effects of radiotherapy. To do so, visualisation is necessary of physiological processes of tumour cells, which are present before macroscale structural changes occur. State-of-the-art MRI techniques are now in use at the Erasmus MC that can assess these physiological processes, including oxygenation status and cell proliferation. We aim to generate proof-of-concept of using a physiological CTV for radiotherapy treatment planning for patients with brain tumours. By extending the clinical standard MRI session used for radiotherapy planning in patients diagnosed with glioblastoma with advanced MRI techniques that assess oxygenation status and cell proliferation, we will generate the physiological CTV including this information and illustrate that it is more precise in capturing microscale tumour invasion. This proof-of-principle work will be used to obtain external funding to perform the much needed, and the first of its kind globally, clinical trial to show the benefit of a physiological CTV for radiotherapy treatment planning in glioblastoma.

A diagnosis of cancer reverberates throughout the family. Family caregivers take on a wide range of responsibilities, such as monitoring medical symptoms, communicating with the patient's medical team, managing insurance claims, providing transportation, and assisting with activities of daily living. Psychological distress is common. Caregivers often feel unprepared for their role, and socially isolated from others. Physical impacts have also been documented, from fatigue to sleep disturbance to immune dysfunction. To alleviate some of these difficult sequelae of cancer caregiving, we propose to test the utility of a brief, low-cost, non-pharmacologic, behavioral intervention for persons providing care for a loved one with cancer. Specifically, we will test the effects of an expressive writing (EW) intervention. The basic paradigm asks participants to write for 20 minutes on four separate occasions about a trauma or stressor. Initial work conducted with undergraduate samples showed benefit of EW. Since then, EW studies have been conducted across a variety of populations including persons coping with chronic illness. Benefits have ranged from better lung function among asthmatics to fewer physical symptoms among women with breast cancer. One meta-analysis of 146 studies across 10,94 participants reported positive effect sizes (mental or physical health benefits) for 102 of the studies (70%). Notable gaps in this literature include testing with cancer caregivers (with some exceptions) and use of novel delivery formats. Specific aims are: (1) To examine the effects of a group-based, videoconference-delivered EW program on emotional, social, and physical well-being among informal caregivers of persons diagnosed with cancer; (2) To identify social and linguistic mechanisms by which participation in the group-based EW intervention may improve distress; and (3) To identify potential moderators of benefit including age, gender identity, relationship to the patient, and baseline social constraints.

However, research has found that this is not the case and that interventions that are not adapted to an individual's culture and ethnicity do not work as well and are not used as frequently. In this project, we compare two methods of stakeholder engagement, Design Thinking (DT) and Focus Groups (FG), to determine which is better at getting input on the facilitators and barriers to access therapy for autistic children. We focus on Hispanics and Latinos as this is the largest minority group in the US, with one of the fastest-growing groups of autistic children. Our long-term objective is to improve the functional skills and health of Hispanic/Latino autistic children and their families by improving access to an occupational therapy intervention designed to improve daily living skills, socialization, and quality of life.
Occupational therapy using Ayres Sensory Integration (OT/ASI) is the only evidence-based intervention that addresses the sensory symptoms in autism. We will use input from these engagement sessions to adapt two versions of the OT/ASI manual: one using DT data and the other using FG data. Outcomes are evaluated following each step. Following the completion of this project, the planned outputs of the study are data on the most effective minority stakeholder engagement method and a culturally adapted OT/ASI manual for Hispanic and Latino autistic children for clinicians and researchers. This information can support future researchers who are engaging Hispanic/Latino individuals or other minority groups in research.

The flipped learning model offers students and faculty members the opportunity to teach a course other than the traditional one. It is a blended teaching method in which the activities carried out in the classroom are integrated outside the classroom and the teaching activities carried out outside the classroom are integrated into the classroom. In this model, students can access videos, presentations or recordings prepared as course materials before coming to class, through technological devices such as computers, tablets and smartphones. Students have the opportunity to watch and listen to the prepared course content wherever and whenever they want, as many times as they want. Watching as many resources as they want according to their own learning speed brings about effective and easy learning. Afterwards, when the student comes to the classroom, the information learned is reinforced by the instructor, and the areas that are not understood are solved with questions and answers. Lesson hours for students who take an active role in the classroom are also important in terms of using time effectively. The student is at the center of this learning method and the student assumes individual learning responsibility. Considering nursing education within the scope of all these beneficial results, it is obvious that effective learning will be achieved. This study aimed to help students easily adapt to the principles of asepsis. Videos containing the principles of asepsis will be presented to the experimental group students 2 weeks before the infection control course (11/11/2023). Normal lecture and practice periods will begin between (11/11/2023-12/12/2023) and the education will last 4 weeks in total. When the study period ends, students will be given a knowledge test and then again 2 weeks later. The implementation period of the study will last until 20/12/2023. Control group students will be educated only during the normal course. The research will be conducted with first-year students of Bilecik Şeyh Edebali University Nursing Department.

CMV infection is common in liver transplant recipients, and CMV disease is one of the most common complications after liver transplantation. CMV disease can lead to graft failure, organ dysfunction, and even death. In addition, the treatment of CMV disease is difficult, and the prognosis is poor. Therefore, it is of great significance to study the epidemiology of CMV disease in liver transplant recipients.
This study is a prospective observational study. The investigators will enroll liver transplant recipients within 10 days after transplantation and follow them up for 12 months. The investigators will collect clinical data, CMV serology, and CMV DNA detection results. The investigators will analyze the incidence of CMV disease in liver transplant recipients, the risk factors for CMV disease, and the clinical characteristics of CMV disease. The investigators will also analyze the treatment and prognosis of CMV disease.
The investigators hope that this study can provide a basis for the prevention and treatment of CMV disease in liver transplant recipients.

SN causes people to ignore or be unaware of objects and people on the left side of their body and space. This can cause dangerous consequences, such as not realizing they are in the middle of the road when walking, or not being able to use their left arm or leg. Although Veterans with SN are half as likely to return home, have one-third the community mobility, require 3x as much caregiver supervision, and have longer hospitalizations compared with similar right brain stroke survivors, a personalized approach to SN rehabilitation is not available in Veteran-specific systems of care. The investigators discovered that frontal lobe damage and Aiming SN both predict optimal recovery of functional independence after prism adaptation treatment (PAT). These findings argue for the development of an objective, biomarker-based process to identify patients who should be administered PAT. The algorithm will be developed by identifying specific neurobiological features predictive of PAT treatment response. Thus, the investigators expect this research will deliver a critical missing element to rehabilitation, eliminating clinician uncertainty about SN diagnosis and appropriateness of PAT, and allowing a more personalized health care approach to SN rehabilitation. The team of researchers at three high-performing VA medical centers, distinguished in cognitive neurology analysis of brain imaging predictors, and stroke rehabilitation, from both advanced and clinical data, will develop the first biological parameter that can be used to assign SN rehabilitation. In 180 Veterans (120 with SN, 60 without), the investigators will define and validate brain imagining biomarkers that predict the presence of Aiming SN (Aim 1), a strong predictor of functional recovery after receiving PAT. Currently, brain tumors are detected by means of an imaging technique (usually magnetic resonance imaging) with a contrast agent. The determination of the type of tumor, as well as its grading, is usually done subsequently with a biopsy of the tissue, where different solid samples are extracted as representative as possible to analyze them in the Pathological Anatomy service. Nevertheless, there are some factors that limit surgical access, such as: the advanced age of the patient, the location of the tumor in eloquent or risky areas, as well as the presence of large tumors with very diffuse borders. In these cases, the diagnosis of the brain tumor is usually made directly with the magnetic resonance image, which implies a risk of error due to the lack of clinical information from this test. Limitations like these make the minimally invasive procedure of liquid biopsy an extremely necessary diagnostic tool. For this reason, the investigators want to start a pilot study of this technique in those patients with brain lesions in the resonance images compatible with a glioma-like tumor. In particular, the main aim of the study is to analyze the blood samples obtained from these patients in order to detect and quantify the circulating DNA (ctDNA) of tumor cells on it. These DNA fragments are expelled into the bloodstream by mechanisms still unknown as a result of numerous processes of apoptosis and necrosis of tumor cells. By analyzing them through a ddPCR, the investigators will try to detect the specific mutations present in this tumoral ctDNA, allowing the team to confirm the presence of a glioma-type tumor, and providing real-time information of its classification as astrocytoma or oligodendroglioma.

However, air traps in clinical use have limited capacity to prevent from microemboli of air to enter the return bloodline and deposit as emboli in the body such as lungs, heart and brain. The Investigator developed the air trap Emboless that was patented in Europe, USA and India. In vitro studies showed significantly better reduction of microemboli contaminations than air traps compared to that in clinical use. The present randomized clinical trial compares two different air traps used by the same patients in a cross-over design (as pairs) using the Emboless compared with the Fresenius 4008/5008 (F5008). Each patient is included to make two paired series. A maximum of 30 patients are planned. Each with 2 series of each two different sets of air traps that would give a total of 120 dialyses. A safety committee evaluates if significantly worse outcome appears especially with the Emboless. During HD the microbubbles are counted by a GAMPT ultrasound device using two probes. One probe is set at the inlet side of the air trap and the second at the outlet side. The outlet side represents data of microbubbles in the blood that are entering into the patient. Comparative non-parametric paired analyses are performed between the air traps.

Laparoscopic pancreaticoduodenectomy (LPD) is the standard treatment for periampullary tumors. The incidence of postoperative pancreatic fistula (POPF) is the most important factor affecting the short-term and long-term outcomes of LPD. The incidence of POPF is related to the level of pancreatic neck transection. The higher the level of pancreatic neck transection, the higher the incidence of POPF. However, the level of pancreatic neck transection is related to the location of the main pancreatic duct. The higher the level of pancreatic neck transection, the more likely the main pancreatic duct is located in the pancreatic stump, which increases the risk of POPF. Therefore, the level of pancreatic neck transection should be as low as possible. However, the main pancreatic duct is often located in the posterior part of the pancreatic neck, and the conventional pancreatic neck transection is performed at the anterior edge of the pancreatic neck, which may lead to the devascularization of the pancreatic stump and increase the incidence of POPF. In order to reduce the incidence of POPF, some scholars have proposed to perform extended pancreatic neck transection, that is, to transect the pancreatic neck at the posterior edge of the pancreatic neck. The purpose of this study is to compare the incidence of POPF between extended pancreatic neck transection and conventional pancreatic neck transection during LPD.

These sickle-shaped cells are rigid and cannot move through small blood vessels as easily as normal red blood cells. This can slow or block blood flow to the limbs, organs, and tissues. Sickle cell crisis is a sudden and severe worsening of the disease. It can cause episodes of pain, swelling, and infection. It can also lead to organ damage.

The aim of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of barbed sutures in vaginal cuff closure after total laparoscopic hysterectomy.
The study is a multicenter, parallel arms, open-label, randomized controlled trial.
The study population will consist of women undergoing elective total laparoscopic hysterectomy for benign pathology.
The patients will be randomized to undergo vaginal cuff closure with a barbed suture or with a standard absorbable suture.
The primary outcome is the occurrence of vaginal cuff dehiscence within 30 days and 90 days after surgery.
Secondary outcomes are:
vaginal cuff complications (hematoma, abscess, infections, bleeding, resuture of the vaginal cuff)
hospital stay

quality of life index (Short Form 12 Health Survey)
sexual function (Female Sexual Function Index)

Gambling addiction has often been conceptualized as the result of reward processing dysfunction in the brain, particularly in the striatum, a key structure of the reward system. Although a number of studies have provided support for this hypothesis, neuroimaging studies have produced inconsistent results, suggesting either hypo- or hyper-reactivity to rewards in gambling addiction. These inconsistencies have been the subject of intense debate, but remain unexplained to this day, hampering our understanding of the disease and the development of effective therapeutic strategies.
The aim of this project is to test a new neurobiological model of gambling addiction that has the potential to reconcile these inconsistencies. A particular feature of this model is that it takes into account inter-individual differences, as well as the multifactorial nature of gaming addiction.
Primary objective: This project will test the hypothesis that there are two opposite brain phenotypes in gambling addiction: striatal hyper-reactivity to reward combined with amygdala hypo-reactivity to emotional stimuli, and striatal hypo-reactivity to reward combined with amygdala hyper-reactivity to emotional stimuli. The investigators further hypothesize that these two brain phenotypes characterize two distinct subpopulations of gamblers, so-called impulsive vs. emotional gamblers, respectively.
Secondary objective: This project will also seek to determine whether the brain phenotypes proposed above are capable of predicting gambling behavior outside the laboratory. To do this, the investigators will use Ecological Momentary Assessment (EMA), which involves using participants' smartphones to perform repeated, real-time sampling of their gambling behavior and emotions in real life. The investigators hypothesize that a significant difference in reactivity between the striatum and the amygdala will be associated with a strong correlation between 1) gambling behavior and positive emotions in impulsive gamblers, and 2) gambling behavior and negative emotions in emotional gamblers.

The aim of this study is to determine the effects of breast cancer (BC) risk assessment and counselling on adherence to risk reduction recommendations among female relatives of BC patients in Southwestern Nigeria. This is a randomized controlled trial. The study population will consist of first-degree female relatives of histologically confirmed BC patients in Southwestern Nigeria. Participants will be recruited from the University College Hospital (UCH), Ibadan, and the University of Ilorin Teaching Hospital (UITH), Ilorin. The sample size of 380 was calculated using the formula for comparison of two proportions. The study will be conducted in two phases. In the first phase, participants will be recruited and baseline data will be collected using a structured questionnaire. Participants in the control group will receive standard care (SC) which will consist of one-on-one breast cancer awareness education; one-on-one monthly Breast Self-Examination (BSE) training; general breast cancer screening recommendations; and general lifestyle modification recommendations. Participants in the intervention group will receive SC as described above in addition to individualized BC risk assessment, individualized BC risk counselling, and lifestyle risk reduction recommendations. Data will be analyzed using the Statistical Package for Social Sciences (SPSS) version 20.0. Categorical variables will be presented as frequencies and percentages, and continuous variables will be presented as means and standard deviations. The purpose of this study is to determine the effect of a commonly prescribed HIV medication, efavirenz, on the disposition and pharmacodynamics of the pain medication tizanidine and the anti-anxiety medication methadone in healthy volunteers. Efavirenz is a medication used to treat HIV infection. It is a potent inducer of certain liver enzymes, including CYP2B6, an enzyme that metabolizes many medications. Tizanidine and methadone are both substrates of CYP2B6. CYP2B6 is a gene that is present in most people but is either not active (poor metabolizer), less active (intermediate metabolizer), or fully active (normal metabolizer). The activity of CYP2B6 can be increased or decreased by genetic factors. Efavirenz can increase the activity of CYP2B6. The purpose of this study is to determine the effect of efavirenz on the disposition and pharmacodynamics of methadone and tizanidine in healthy volunteers with different levels of CYP2B6 activity.
Disposition refers to the way in which a drug is metabolized and eliminated by the body. Pharmacodynamics refers to the way in which a drug affects the body.
Healthy volunteers between the ages of 18 and 65 years of age who are either normal metabolizers, intermediate metabolizers, or poor metabolizers of CYP2B6 may be eligible for this study. Candidates will be screened with a medical history, physical examination, blood and urine tests, and an electrocardiogram (EKG).
Participants will be admitted to the NIH Clinical Center for two 24-hour periods. During each admission, participants will receive a single dose of methadone and tizanidine. The most common material used for the manufacture of dental implants is titanium, due to its biocompatibility and mechanical properties. However, the use of this material has some disadvantages, such as the fact that it is a dark gray color, which makes it difficult to place anatomical restorations, or that it can cause an allergic reaction in some patients.
In recent years, the use of zirconia as a material for manufacturing dental implants has increased. Zirconia is a white material, which allows the placement of anatomical restorations without the need for abutments of different colors. In addition, it is a biocompatible material, which has mechanical properties similar to titanium.
There are studies that have analyzed the presence of bacteria on the surface of zirconia abutments, but there are no studies that have compared the presence of bacteria on the surface of zirconia implants with titanium implants.
The objective of this study is to compare the presence of bacteria on the surface of zirconia implants with titanium implants. For this, a clinical trial will be carried out in which 30 patients will be included, who will receive a zirconia implant in one jaw and a titanium implant in the other jaw. This study is being done to see if a different way of finding and removing lymph nodes during surgery, using a special camera and a dye called Indocyanine Green (ICG), works as well as the usual method with blue dye plus a radioactive tracer called radiocolloid. By comparing the two ways directly, we hope to make it simpler for people with vulvar cancer to get their lymph nodes checked during surgery.
Indocyanine green (ICG) is a fluorescent dye that has been used for the imaging of cancers in the body for more than 30 years. It is approved by the FDA for use in patients. It is given as an injection into the skin near the tumor. A special camera that detects the fluorescence of ICG is then used to look for lymph nodes that have taken up the dye. These lymph nodes are called sentinel lymph nodes. They are the first lymph nodes that the cancer is likely to spread to. Removal of these lymph nodes during surgery can help determine if the cancer has spread beyond the vulva.
The usual method of finding sentinel lymph nodes involves injecting a blue dye and a radioactive tracer into the skin near the tumor. The blue dye can be seen with the naked eye, and the radioactive tracer can be detected with a special probe. The lymph nodes that take up the dye and/or are hot (have the radioactive tracer) are then removed during surgery.
In this study, we will compare the results of using ICG alone with the usual method of using blue dye and a radioactive tracer. We will look at how many sentinel lymph nodes are found using each method, and we will compare the size and location of the sentinel lymph nodes. We will also look at how many patients have additional lymph nodes that need to be removed because they are hot or contain cancer cells.
The results of this study will help us determine if ICG alone can be used instead of the usual method for finding sentinel lymph nodes in patients with vulvar cancer.

Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) is a severe fungal infection of the lungs, which is often lethal. It is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in immunocompromised patients, especially in those with hematological malignancies and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). The diagnosis of IPA is difficult and often delayed. The gold standard for diagnosis is histopathological evidence of invasive hyphal growth in tissue, but this is often unavailable. The diagnosis is therefore often made on the basis of imaging, serology and fungal culture. However, these methods are not very sensitive and the diagnosis is often made too late. This is especially problematic in the case of HSCT, where the diagnosis is often made too late, after the patient has already developed severe lung damage.
The development of a non-invasive diagnostic method for IPA is therefore of great importance. In recent years, there has been growing interest in the use of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) as a diagnostic tool for various diseases. VOCs are organic compounds that are present in the exhaled air of patients. These compounds can be used as markers for various diseases.
In this study, the investigators aim to investigate whether VOCs can be used to diagnose IPA in patients with hematological malignancies and HSCT. The investigators will collect breath samples from patients and analyze the VOC profile in these samples. The investigators will then compare the VOC profile of patients with IPA to the VOC profile of patients without IPA. The investigators hope that this study will contribute to the development of a non-invasive diagnostic method for IPA.

Lung transplantation is the only treatment that can prolong survival for patients with end-stage lung disease. However, the long-term prognosis of lung transplantation is still poor, and the median survival time is only 5.5 years. The most common cause of death after lung transplantation is chronic lung allograft dysfunction (CLAD), which is a progressive deterioration of pulmonary function and gas exchange. The pathogenesis of CLAD is not fully understood, and there is currently no effective treatment. Therefore, it is very important to study the pathological changes of CLAD and explore new treatment methods.
Lung biopsy is an important method to study the pathological changes of CLAD. Traditional lung biopsy is performed by bronchoscopy with biopsy forceps, which can only obtain a small amount of tissue. The pathological changes of CLAD are diffuse and subtle, and it is easy to miss the lesions. In recent years, cryobiopsy has been widely used in the field of pulmonary interstitial disease. Compared with traditional biopsy, cryobiopsy can obtain larger tissue samples, which is conducive to the study of pathological changes. In addition, the use of cryoprobe can reduce the damage to the bronchial mucosa and reduce the complications of lung biopsy.
In this study, the investigators will use a 1.1mm flexible cryoprobe to perform transbronchial lung cryobiopsy in patients with lung transplantation. The investigators will compare the diagnostic efficacy of transbronchial cryobiopsy with traditional transbronchial lung biopsy. The investigators will also evaluate the incidence of complications and the quality of the biopsy specimens. The results of this study will provide a basis for the clinical application of transbronchial lung cryobiopsy in the field of lung transplantation.
