Selective fetal growth restriction (sFGR) in monochorionic twins may negatively impact the pregnancy. There is a substantial risk of fetal deterioration resulting in (iatrogenic) preterm birth or even intrauterine demise of one, or both fetuses. There are important unresolved challenges on a diagnostic level and underlying pathophysiological mechanisms of sFGR have not been fully clarified. The current diagnostic classification system based on three different umbilical artery flow patterns has no increasing scale of severity and the observed flow patterns may be volatile in nature. This hinders optimal diagnostic management and complicates outcome prediction as the survival outcome differs per umbilical artery flow type. Consequently, parents encounter a great deal of uncertainty during the pregnancy. Since there is no treatment available for sFGR, predicting fetal deterioration is key in preventing single or double demise. By testing several predictors, the investigators are aiming to improve outcome prediction at the time of sFGR diagnosis. The investigators furthermore hypothesize that additional ultrasound parameters could be of benefit in making the current classification system more accurate and less variable. Extensive histological placental examinations will shine a light on microscopic abnormalities which can increase our knowledge of the pathophysiology. Examining neurodevelopment of sFGR twins at two years of age will additionally be of great value for our understanding of the impact of sFGR and contribute to adequate patient counselling.

The investigators will develop and pilot test a free mobile- and web-enabled platform for transgender and gender-diverse (TGD) youth and their caregivers that combines educational modules with high-quality, evidence-based information and interactive features. The investigators will conduct a randomized controlled trial to test the effectiveness of the platform in reducing suicidal ideation and improving mental health outcomes among TGD youth. The investigators will also assess the impact of the platform on caregiver support and communication. The investigators will recruit 500 TGD youth and their caregivers and randomize them to an Immediate Arm (access to a digital platform, plus usual care) or a Deferred Arm (usual care; access to the digital platform at 6 mo). Usual care consists of access to published resources and community support organizations, if available. The list of resources will include contact information for a suicide prevention hotline. For each Arm, the intervention period will last 6 months, followed by 12 months of observation, during which access to the intervention is maintained. Assessments will be performed every 3 months over the 18 month period to document changes in mental health outcomes and the two groups will be compared. The investigators hypothesize that TGD youth who have access to the digital platform will have a greater reduction in suicidal ideation and a greater improvement in mental health outcomes compared to those who do not have access to the platform. The investigators also hypothesize that TGD youth who have access to the digital platform will have an increase in perceived caregiver support and communication compared to those who do not have access to the platform.

Transcranial focused ultrasound (tFUS) uses a single transducer fixed in a head-worn apparatus on the scalp to produce ultrasonic waves deep into the brain.
The main outcomes of this study are brain imaging related. Using a neuroimaging technique called resting state functional connectivity, which is a statistical dependence between time series of electro-physiological activity and (de)oxygenated blood levels in distinct regions of the brain. Functional connectivity strength calculation determines whether the activity between a pair of brain regions covaries or correlates over time. Type-2 diabetes (T2D) is a chronic disease that affects the way the body processes blood sugar (glucose). Over time, high blood sugar levels can damage the blood vessels and nerves in the body, leading to serious health problems. One of the most common health problems associated with T2D is stroke. Stroke occurs when the blood supply to the brain is interrupted, either by a blockage or a bleed. This can cause brain cells to die, resulting in permanent damage.
Recent studies have shown that a new drug called semaglutide can help to reduce the risk of stroke in people with T2D. Semaglutide is a type of drug called a glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist (GLP-1 RA). It works by mimicking the actions of a hormone called glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1), which is produced by the body in response to rising blood sugar levels. GLP-1 helps to control blood sugar levels by stimulating the production of insulin.
The exact mechanism by which semaglutide reduces the risk of stroke is not fully understood. It is possible that semaglutide improves blood flow to the brain, or that it reduces inflammation in the brain.
In this study, the investigators will use magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to investigate the effects of semaglutide on blood flow to the brain and the blood-brain barrier (BBB) in people with T2D. The BBB is a barrier that separates the blood from the brain tissue. It helps to protect the brain from harmful substances in the blood.
The investigators will also measure levels of inflammatory markers in the blood. Inflammation is a process that is involved in the development of stroke.
The investigators will recruit 100 people with T2D and randomly assign them to receive either semaglutide or a placebo (a dummy drug). The study will last for 1 year. During this time, the investigators will perform MRA and MRI scans at the beginning of the study and at the end of the study. The investigators will also take blood samples at the beginning of the study and at the end of the study.

The aim of this study is to evaluate the accuracy of the brain response evoked by radiofrequency (RF) and mechanical stimuli in healthy volunteers.
The brain response to painful stimuli can be measured by electroencephalography (EEG). This response is called evoked potential (EP). EPs are a reliable and objective alternative to evaluate the state of the nociceptive system. However, the stimuli used to evoke these EPs are not always available.
The RF stimulation is a new alternative to evoke EPs. It is safe, relatively inexpensive, and in widespread use in clinics. The RF stimulation is similar to contact heat, but it has the advantage that it can be applied with a high degree of control and precision.
Another attractive alternative to subjective evaluation is the EP evoked by sharp mechanical stimuli. A device that applies this type of stimulus has recently been developed. It uses a stimulator with a tip similar to that of a blunt needle, which allows obtaining brain responses synchronized with the stimulus and evaluating the state of the spino-thalamic-cortical mechanical sensory conduction pathways.
In this study, the precision of the brain response to RF and mechanical sharp stimuli will be evaluated in two experimental settings. We plan to assess the effect of stimulation intensity on signal parameters, such as EP latency and amplitude. Furthermore, the relationship of these parameters with psychophysical results (questionnaires) and heat thresholds will be explored to investigate the relationship between these variables.

In Canada, women are less likely to have their blood pressure under control. Home blood pressure monitors (HBPM) are an effective tool to help patients reach their blood pressure targets. Community pharmacists are accessible health care providers who are well positioned to help patients manage their blood pressure. The aim of this study is to determine the impact of HBPM when used in addition to pharmacist care, compared to usual care, in women with blood pressure elevated above their target level.

Enhancing our ability to determine the optimal intervention for a particular patient has the potential to enhance the overall effectiveness of mental health care delivery in a more cost-efficient manner. This is a critical gap in knowledge in the treatment of depression across clinical settings globally.
The main objective of the OptimizeD study is to determine whether different patients respond differentially to brief psychological treatment based on behavioral activation called the Healthy Activity Program (HAP) or antidepressant medication (fluoxetine) and, if so, whether one can optimize outcomes in a cost-effective fashion for primary care patients with moderate to severe depression. The study has two specific aims and two exploratory aims:
Specific Aim 1 (Clinical and Functional Outcomes): To evaluate the effectiveness of optimization via generating a precision treatment rule (PTR) on patients with moderate to severe depression randomized to either psychotherapy based on behavioral activation called the Healthy Activity Program (HAP) or antidepressant medication (fluoxetine). The study will use machine learning to develop the PTR, using a wide range of clinical, socio-economic, and neuro-cognitive characteristics measured at baseline as predictors. The investigators hypothesize that patients randomized by chance to their optimal intervention will be more likely to remit and recover than patients who are not.
Specific Aim 2 (Cost-effectiveness Outcomes): To assess the costs of optimal vs. non-optimal treatments and to conduct a cost-effectiveness analysis by comparing relative costs and effectiveness between those who were randomly allocated to their optimal treatment with those who were randomly allocated to a non-optimal treatment, based on the PTR developed in Aim 1. The investigators hypothesize that optimizing will be more cost-effective than not.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic disease that affects the whole body and requires long-term treatment. The disease is characterized by periods of remission and relapse. The most common symptoms are diarrhea, abdominal pain, fatigue, and weight loss. The disease can also cause complications such as intestinal bleeding, perforation, and abscesses.
Surgery is often needed in IBD, for example, to remove parts of the intestine that are no longer functioning properly or to treat complications. However, there is a shortage of surgeons and operating rooms in Sweden, which means that many patients have to wait a long time for surgery. This can be difficult for the patients, who may experience increased symptoms and reduced quality of life.
In this study, the investigators want to investigate how a long waiting time for surgery affects the patients' health economy and quality of life. The investigators will also look at whether the waiting time affects the outcome of the surgery. The investigators will use data from the Swedish IBD-register and the Swedish National Board for Health and Welfare. The investigators will also interview patients who have had surgery for IBD. The results from this study can help to improve the care of patients with IBD in Sweden.

Sudden sensorineural hearing loss (SSNHL) is a common disease of the auditory system, which is characterized by rapid onset of hearing loss within 72 hours, and the hearing loss is usually unilateral. The incidence of SSNHL is 5-20 cases per 100,000 people per year, and the incidence of SSNHL in China is 15-30 cases per 100,000 people per year. The pathogenesis of SSNHL is unclear, and the current treatment is limited. The 2019 American Academy of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery (AAO-HNS) Guidelines recommend that patients with SSNHL should be treated with systemic steroids as the first choice. However, the efficacy of systemic steroids is limited, and the recurrence rate is as high as 10%. Therefore, it is of great significance to find new drugs for the treatment of SSNHL.
Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) is an endogenous coenzyme that participates in various metabolic reactions in the body. Studies have found that NAD+ can promote the regeneration of hair cells and improve hearing loss. Coenzyme I (NADH) is the reduced form of NAD+. Studies have found that Coenzyme I can promote the proliferation and differentiation of inner ear cells, and can also promote the regeneration of damaged auditory nerves. Therefore, Coenzyme I is expected to be a new drug for the treatment of SSNHL.
This study is a single-center, randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, placebo-controlled trial. The investigators will recruit 100 patients with SSNHL and randomly divide them into two groups: the experimental group and the control group. The experimental group will be treated with Coenzyme I for injection and conventional treatment for 7 consecutive days, and the control group will be treated with conventional treatment for 7 consecutive days. The primary outcome is pure tone average (PTA). The secondary outcomes include speech recognition rate, tinnitus handicap inventory (THI), tinnitus visual analogue scale (VAS), and the severity of ear fullness.

Hemodiafiltration (HDF) is a blood purification technology that combines hemodialysis and continuous hemofiltration. Compared with conventional hemodialysis (HD), HDF can effectively remove middle molecules and large molecules, and has the advantages of reducing the concentration gradient of small molecules, reducing the burden on the heart and vascular access, and improving the clearance of toxins and fluid. However, the clinical benefits of HDF are still controversial. The main reason is that the conventional HDF mode uses post-dilution to replace the dialysate with a large amount of substitution fluid, which will dilute the patient's blood and reduce the clearance of small molecules. In addition, the use of a large amount of substitution fluid will increase the burden of the circulation system and the risk of hypotension. In order to solve the above problems, the investigators developed a new HDF mode-hemodiafiltration with endogenous reinfusion (HFR). In this mode, the blood purification machine is equipped with a reinfusion pump, and the patient's own blood is reinfused after purification, which can effectively improve the clearance of small molecules and reduce the dilution of blood. In addition, the use of endogenous blood reinfusion can reduce the use of substitution fluid, reduce the burden on the circulation system, and reduce the risk of hypotension. The investigators conducted a single-center, open-label, single-arm clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of HFR. The investigators will enroll 20 patients with end-stage renal disease who are undergoing maintenance hemodialysis. The investigators will use HFR to treat patients for 4 hours, and compare the clearance of uremic toxins before and after treatment. The investigators will also evaluate the safety of HFR. The investigators expect that HFR can effectively remove uremic toxins and improve the efficacy of blood purification.

Ischemic stroke remains a leading cause of death and long-term disability worldwide,1 despite major advancements in reperfusion therapies.2,3 While neuroimaging modalities have expanded patient eligibility for reperfusion therapies by estimating ischemic core and salvageable tissue,4-7 their assessments are mostly single-timed. Currently available clinical algorithms lack the capacity to continuously track the dynamic evolution of how the primary core progresses to a final infarct, which, however, is a major determinant of functional outcome.8-10 Monitoring infarct trajectories could support therapeutic decision-making in patients with large-vessel occlusion stroke and unveil determinants of stroke progression, aiding in patient selection for trials evaluating cytoprotection11 and targeting clinically ineffective reperfusion.12 Previously studied blood-based biomarkers such as Neurofilament Light Chain (NfL),13 neuron-specific enolase (NSE),14 glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP),15,16 and S 100 calcium-binding protein B (S100B)17 either failed to capture the extent of brain injury within the acute phase of stroke or lack specificity. Plasma levels of brain-derived tau (BD-tau) were recently found to show high value for monitoring brain injury in patients with acute IS: In 502 patients with acute IS, plasma BD-tau was associated with imaging-based metrics of brain injury upon admission, increased within the first 24 hours in correlation with infarct progression, and at 24 hours was superior to final infarct volume in predicting 90-day functional outcome.18 While informing on the relation of BD-tau with imaging-based metrics of brain injury, this large cross-sectional study was restricted to BD-tau assessments upon admission (median time from onset: 4.4 hours) and at day 2 (median time from onset: 22.7 hours) and could not inform on key characteristics of the evolution of plasma BD-tau, including when exactly it starts to rise, how long it continues to rise, and how it is determined by infarct characteristics

Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) is the most common cancer in Caucasians. The majority of cSCC are curable with surgical excision. However, cSCC can be aggressive in certain patient populations. Patients who are immunosuppressed, have a history of previous cancer, or have cSCC that is large or has high-risk features are at a higher risk of developing nodal metastases. The Brigham and Women's Hospital (BWH) staging system is a tool that is used to determine the risk of nodal metastases in patients with cSCC. Patients with high-risk primary cSCC are recommended to undergo a sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) to detect nodal metastases. SLNB is a procedure where a radioactive dye is injected around the tumor and follows the lymphatic pathway to the first lymph node that drains the area. The first lymph node is removed and examined under a microscope to determine if there are any tumor cells present. If the SLNB is negative, the patient is considered to be free of nodal disease.
Currently, there are no guidelines for the surveillance of nodal basins in patients with high-risk primary cSCC who have a negative SLNB. The purpose of this study is to determine the rate of nodal metastases in patients with high-risk primary cSCC who have a negative SLNB. Patients will be followed for 2 years with ultrasound examinations of the nodal basins every 6 months. The investigators hypothesize that the rate of nodal metastases in this patient population is low and that ultrasound surveillance every 6 months is a reasonable alternative to SLNB.

Gastroesophageal reflux (GER) is a very common condition in infants, which usually resolves spontaneously within the first year of life. In some cases, however, GER can evolve into gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which is characterized by the presence of symptoms and complications. The diagnosis of GERD is based on the integration of clinical data, such as symptoms, and instrumental data, such as pH-impedance monitoring. The latter is considered the gold standard for the diagnosis of GERD. However, pH-impedance monitoring is an invasive and expensive test, which is not always available. Therefore, it would be useful to identify non-invasive and inexpensive diagnostic tools for the diagnosis of GERD.
Saliva is a biological fluid that is easy to collect and that contains a large number of biomarkers. In recent years, several studies have shown that the composition of saliva can be altered in patients with gastrointestinal diseases. However, there is no information on the possible role of saliva as a diagnostic tool for GERD in infants.
The aim of this study is to investigate the possible role of saliva as a diagnostic tool for GERD in infants. To this end, the investigators will collect saliva samples from infants with GERD undergoing pH-impedance monitoring and from healthy infants. The investigators will analyze the salivary biochemical profile of the two groups of infants and will correlate the results with the data obtained from pH-impedance monitoring.
The results of this study could lead to the development of a non-invasive and inexpensive diagnostic test for the diagnosis of GERD in infants.

Choroidal melanoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults, thus being the focus of extensive research. The primary treatment goals of this disease consist in controlling local disease, reducing the risk of distant metastases, and avoiding enucleation whenever possible. Plaque brachytherapy is currently the standard treatment for small and medium-sized uveal melanomas. In clinical practice, ruthenium (Ru-106) or iodine (I-125) are the most commonly employed radioisotopes. Ruthenium is the most utilized radioisotope in Europe and South America due to its availability and good clinical outcomes. It is currently the only available option in Brazil's public health system (SUS). However, its use for large tumors (greater than 10 mm in thickness and/or 22 mm in diameter) is limited by the inability of delivering an adequate therapeutic dose of radiation without causing further damage to the surrounding retinal tissue. For this reason, researchers in medical physics have been investigating new treatment options in the last decades, including external beam radiotherapy (EBRT), radiosurgery (gamma knife or linear accelerator), and proton beam therapy. Although gamma knife radiosurgery and proton beam therapy are effective treatments with reliable tumor control rates, they are associated with poor visual outcomes, inadequate globe retention, and their use is reportedly limited in public health systems of low- or middle-income countries. EBRT carries potential side effects related to a broader radiation field, with an increased risk for complications in ocular and periocular structures, such as eyelids, sclera, lens, and retina. Finally, enucleation is an effective management for very large tumors, but it is usually a last resource. Considering the above-mentioned treatment limitations for large choroidal melanomas, our group explored an alternative approach using intra-arterial chemotherapy (IAC) for tumor chemoreduction, aiming to reduce thickness and allow subsequent brachytherapy using a Ru-106 plaque. Intra-arterial chemotherapy (IAC) with melphalan has been used to treat multiple cancers, including liver metastases from uveal and skin melanomas

Some technical (i.e., bowel preparation) and operator-related (i.e., expertise, and fatigue) factors are related to these missing lesions. Down syndrome (DS) is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability. Children with DS have delayed motor development and poor dynamic balance control. Dynamic balance control is the ability to maintain the center of mass within the base of support during voluntary movement of the limbs or during postural adjustments to external or internal perturbations. It is essential for performing daily activities.
The aim of this study is to investigate the effects of weight bearing exercises with and without Jaffrey's core stability exercise training on dynamic balance control and trunk muscles strength in children with DS.
This study is a randomized controlled trial. 30 children with DS will be randomly assigned to either weight bearing exercises group (WBE) or weight bearing exercises with Jaffrey's core stability exercise training group (WBE+JCST). Both groups will receive 10 sessions of 30 minutes per week for 4 weeks. The WBE group will perform weight bearing exercises and the WBE+JCST group will perform weight bearing exercises and Jaffrey's core stability exercise training.
The primary outcome measures are dynamic balance control and trunk muscles strength. Secondary outcome measures are gait parameters and quality of life.
The investigators hypothesized that both groups will show improvement in dynamic balance control and trunk muscles strength. However, the investigators expect that the WBE+JCST group will show greater improvement than the WBE group.

Cardiac surgery under cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) is associated with a high risk of postoperative complications. CPB is an artificial circulation that replaces the function of the heart and lungs during surgery. It is a complex technique that can lead to multiple organ dysfunction. The main risk is related to the lack of oxygen and nutrients supply to the tissues. To date, the optimal management of oxygen supply during CPB remains unclear.
The aim of this study is to evaluate the impact of a new strategy of oxygen supply optimization during CPB on postoperative complications. The investigators will compare the standard care (calculation of oxygen supply using the traditional formula) to a new strategy based on the use of a new software (CONNECT, LivaNova, London, United Kingdom). It is a form of acupuncture that involves applying pressure to specific points on the ear. The therapeutic effects of AA are achieved by stimulating the auricular acupoints, which are believed to be connected to various parts of the body through the nervous system and meridians.
The aim of this study is to investigate the changes in skin surface temperature of the lumbar region during AA at the kidney point on healthy volunteers. The study will be conducted in a controlled environment to minimize external temperature influences. The participants will be randomly divided into two groups: one receiving AA first followed by sham auricular acupressure (SA) (AA-SA group), while the other group will receive SA first followed by AA (SA-AA group). The temperature of the lumbar region will be recorded using an infrared thermal imaging camera before, during, and after the procedures.
The study hypotheses are as follows:
H0: There is no significant change in the temperature of the lumbar region during AA at the kidney point.
H1: There is a significant increase in the temperature of the lumbar region during AA at the kidney point.
H2: There is a significant decrease in the temperature of the lumbar region during AA at the kidney point.
H3: The temperature change in the lumbar region during AA at the kidney point is affected by the order of the procedures.
The study will provide valuable insights into the physiological mechanisms underlying the therapeutic effects of AA. The results will contribute to a better understanding of the auricular-somatic reflex and the potential of AA as a therapeutic intervention.

Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) is a common eye disorder among premature infants that can lead to long-term visual impairments if left untreated. Therefore, finding effective interventions for retinopathy examinations is crucial for improving the overall visual health of these infants. This study aimed to compare the effectiveness of white noise and multisensory stimulation in retinopathy examination on premature infants.
A randomized controlled experimental design was employed, with premature infants as the study participants. The infants were randomly assigned to three groups: the control group, the white noise group, and the multisensory stimulation group. The white noise group received auditory stimulation through the presentation of white noise, while the multisensory stimulation group received additional visual and tactile stimuli during the retinopathy examination. Several outcome measures were used to evaluate the effectiveness of the interventions. These measures included physiological responses (e.g., heart rate, blood pressure), behavioral indicators (e.g., eye movement, crying), and overall examination success rate. The examination success rate was defined as the ability to complete the retinopathy examination without disturbances caused by infant distress or movement.
The study employed trained healthcare professionals who performed retinopathy examinations using standardized procedures. Data collection was conducted in a controlled environment to ensure consistency across three groups. Statistical analyses, such as ANOVA and chi-square tests, were employed to compare the outcomes between the three groups.
The findings of this study have the potential to contribute to the development of effective and well-tolerated retinopathy examination protocols for premature infants. By comparing the effects of white noise and multisensory stimulation, the study aims to provide insights into the most suitable intervention that can optimize the examination process, improve examination success rates, and minimize potential discomfort or distress experienced by infants. It is anticipated that the results of this study will inform healthcare professionals and researchers about the benefits of auditory stimulation (white noise) and the additional advantages of multisensory stimulation during retinopathy examinations. Ultimately, this research aims to enhance the overall quality of care provided to premature infants, leading to improved visual outcomes and long-term well-being for this vulnerable population.

Meibomian gland dysfunction (MGD) is the most common cause of evaporative dry eye. The diagnosis of MGD is based on the presence of typical clinical signs, such as loss of meibomian glands (MGs), MG dysfunction, and MG destruction. The most commonly used grading system for MGs was proposed by Westcott et al. in 2007. This grading system is based on the percentage of the eyelid surface occupied by MGs, which is calculated by dividing the area of the MGs by the area of the whole eyelid. The area of the MGs is determined by counting the number of MG orifices in a predetermined area of the eyelid and multiplying this number by the orifice density (ORI). The ORI is calculated by dividing the Wessel's test line length by the number of MG orifices. The area of the whole eyelid is calculated by dividing the WTW distance of the cornea by 2. The Westcott grading system has been widely used in clinical trials and research studies. However, the calculation of the area of the whole eyelid using the WTW distance of the cornea has been criticized because the WTW distance of the cornea varies among individuals. In this study, the investigators propose a modified calculation formula for the area of the whole eyelid. The investigators will compare the MG grading results using the original and modified calculation formulas in a group of 100 participants. The investigators hypothesize that the modified calculation formula will provide more accurate grading results.

Oral mucositis (OM) is a common and often severe side effect of cancer treatments, including radiotherapy and chemotherapy. OM is characterized by inflammation of the oral mucosa, which leads to pain, ulceration, and infection of the oral cavity. OM is a multifactorial condition, caused by direct damage to the oral mucosa by cancer treatments, as well as by systemic factors such as malnutrition, dehydration, and immunosuppression. OM can have a significant impact on the quality of life of cancer patients, and can also delay cancer treatment, leading to a worse prognosis.
The aim of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of a medical device (Gel X) in the prevention of OM in patients undergoing radiotherapy for head and neck cancer. Gel X is a spray containing zinc gluconate, which has been shown to have anti-inflammatory and wound-healing properties.
The study will be conducted as a single-blind randomized clinical trial. The population will be divided into two groups, receiving respectively the medical device and a solution based on Sodium Bicarbonate (5 g/L). Patients will be randomly assigned to one of the two groups.
The investigational product be administered for 63 days. Patient will use a spray based on zinc gluconate (three times a day) or a solution based on sodium chloride and bicarbonate (5 times a day).
The primary endpoint is the incidence of OM. Secondary endpoints include the time of OM onset, the severity of OM, and the quality of life of patients.
The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

Subacromial pain syndrome (SDS) is the most common shoulder disorder. It is characterized by pain and discomfort in the shoulder region, with or without limitation of movement. The prevalence of SDS is 20%, being the main cause of consultation in primary care. The main causes of SDS are postural and biomechanical alterations, which lead to the activation of nociceptors and the development of pain.
The main objective of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a protocol of therapeutic exercises for the strengthening of the rotator cuff and the scapular muscles, associated with anodal transcranial direct electrical stimulation (tDCS), in the functional recovery of subjects with SDS.
A randomized clinical trial will be carried out, with a control group and an experimental group. The sample will be made up of 64 subjects with SDS, who will be randomly assigned to the control group (CG) or the experimental group (EG). The CG will perform a protocol of therapeutic exercises for the strengthening of the rotator cuff and the scapular muscles, while the EG will perform the same protocol, but while receiving real tDCS. Both groups will receive 24 supervised sessions, once a day, 3 days a week, over a period of 8 weeks. The primary outcome will be pain and disability, measured with the Spanish versions of the Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI) and the Western Ontario Rotator Cuff (WORC) index. Secondary outcomes will be shoulder strength, measured with a digital dynamometer; active range of motion, measured with a goniometer; pressure pain threshold, measured with an algometer; joint position sense, measured with the laser-pointer assisted angle reproduction test (LP-ART); posture, measured with a digital camera and image processing software; subacromial space width, measured with ultrasound; scapulohumeral rhythm, measured with an inclinometer; and scapular muscle activation, measured with surface electromyography. In addition, cortical excitability will be measured with transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) and electroencephalography (EEG).

HBOT is FDA approved for the treatment of decompression sickness, arterial gas embolism, and air or gas embolism. It is also used for the treatment of carbon monoxide poisoning, necrotizing fasciitis, and gangre. HBOT is also used for the treatment of cranial and spinal cord injuries, and is being studied for the treatment of brain injuries, autism, and cerebral palsy.
The purpose of this study is to determine if there is an association between HBOT and change in verbal scores in children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women. Axillary lymph node dissection (ALND) is a standard treatment for breast cancer patients with axillary lymph node involvement. However, ALND can lead to arm lymphedema, which is a chronic debilitating disease. Immediate lymphatic reconstruction (ILR) is a novel technique that can be performed during ALND to preserve the lymphatic vessels and reduce the risk of arm lymphedema. The investigators hypothesize that ILR can reduce the occurrence of arm lymphedema in breast cancer patients after ALND.
The investigators aim to conduct a prospective randomized controlled trial to compare the occurrence of arm lymphedema in breast cancer patients after ALND with or without ILR. The investigators will also compare the drainage amount, occurrence of seroma or lymphocele, and patient reported outcome measures between the two groups.

The investigators will exclude patients who have already had ALND, patients who are going to receive bilateral ALND, and patients who are allergic to the dye used intraoperatively.
The investigators will perform ALND and ILR in the intervention group. The investigators will identify the lymphatic vessels using indocyanine green (ICG) and perform ILR with lymphatico-venous anastomosis (LVA). The investigators will perform ALND only in the control group.
The investigators will measure the arm circumference at the operative side and the contralateral side at the level of the elbow, mid-arm, and wrist every 3 months for 2 years. The investigators will also administer the Lymphatic Functioning, Limb Volume, and Appearance Questionnaire (LYMQ) at baseline and every 3 months for 2 years. The investigators will compare the arm circumference and LYMQ scores between the two groups.

The trained group (TR) will undergo 3 weeks of EEG-NFB training, whereas the control group (CO) will not undergo training. The EEG-NFB training program will involve nine training sessions (three times a week over a 3-week period) each lasting 30 min. EEG-NFB training will be conducted with ProComp Infiniti Encoder and BioGraph Infiniti Software v.5.1.3. The training protocol will be set to decrease the EEG theta/beta ratio (TBR) value. The EEG-NFB training sessions consists of a 20-s baseline period (i.e., with no feedback), 30-min feedback presentation, and another 20-s baseline period. The raw EEG signal, TBR value over time, EEG signal noise, and EEG theta and beta wave amplitudes will be recorded. Cognitive function will be assessed using the Trail Making Test (TMT) and Stroop Test (ST). The TMT and ST will be performed before and after the 3-week EEG-NFB training period. The TMT and ST will be administered in a quiet room with only one and always the same investigator present. The TMT and ST will be preceded by preparatory/training trials, a similar but shorter version of main tests. Before starting each test, subjects will be instructed to concentrate and to make use their maximal attention skills during testing session. In both tests (TMT and ST), the time taken to complete the test will be used as the performance measure, with a shorter time reflecting a better performance. The tests will be administered in a quiet room with only one and always the same investigator present.

Basilar artery occlusion (BAO) is a subtype of acute ischemic stroke with a high mortality rate and severe disability. Endovascular thrombectomy is recommended for patients with BAO within 24 hours of onset. However, the femoral approach is still the most common method for endovascular thrombectomy in patients with BAO. The radial approach has been widely used in patients with anterior circulation stroke, but there is no consensus on the use of the radial approach in patients with BAO. The investigators hypothesize that the radial approach is not inferior to the femoral approach in patients with BAO. The investigators will conduct a multicenter, randomized, controlled, and open trial to compare the radial approach with the femoral approach in patients with BAO. The primary outcome is the proportion of patients with favorable neurological function (defined as mRS score ≤ 3) at 90 days post-operation. The secondary outcomes include the proportion of patients with successful recanalization (defined as modified TICI score 2b or 3), procedure time, and complications. The investigators will enroll 120 patients in this study. The investigators will use the intention-to-treat principle for the analysis. The investigators will perform the per-protocol analysis for the secondary outcomes.

Low back pain is a common musculoskeletal disorder that affects a significant portion of the population. It is defined as pain, muscle tension, or stiffness in the area between the lower ribs and the lower gluteal folds, with or without leg pain. The prevalence of low back pain is high, with an estimated 80% of the population experiencing low back pain at least once in their lifetime. Chronic low back pain, which lasts longer than 12 weeks, is a common type of low back pain that can significantly affect an individual's quality of life.
The aim of this study was to compare the effects of connective tissue massage and classical massage on pain, functional status, and quality of life in patients with chronic non-specific low back pain. The study was designed as a 3-arm randomized controlled trial, parallel-group study with blind outcomes assessor. The study was conducted with 30 participants diagnosed with chronic non-specific low back pain. The participants were randomly divided into three groups: the CTM group (n=10), CM group (n=10), and control group (n=10). The intervention duration was uniform across all groups: 4 consecutive weeks, with 3 sessions per week lasting 15-20 minutes per session. Outcome measurements were taken at the beginning and 4 weeks after the completion of the program.
The CTM group was administered connective tissue massage, which involves manipulating the soft and deep tissues of the body. The CM group was administered classical massage, which involves manipulating the soft tissues of the body. The control group was administered a standardized physiotherapy program that included the application of superficial thermal heat, transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS), and therapatic ultrasound.
The results showed that both connective tissue massage and classical massage were effective in reducing pain, improving functional status, and enhancing quality of life in patients with chronic non-specific low back pain. However, connective tissue massage was found to be more effective in improving lumbar mobility compared to classical massage and the control group.

The goal of this study is to understand how people make inferences about the world around them. Inference is the process of reasoning to conclusions that are not directly observable. Inference is a fundamental component of human cognition, and it is essential for understanding behavior. Inference is also a key component of many scientific theories. For example, inference is used to explain how people make decisions, how they learn, and how they remember information.
The investigators will use a new method called psychophysics to study inference. Insomnia is a highly common, chronic disorder that is distressful for the patient but also for caregivers and can give rise to a heavy burden on the healthcare team. Sleeping aids like benzodiazepines and other sedatives (e.g., zolpidem, zopiclone) have been widely used to help treat insomnia. However, sleeping aids are also known to cause adverse drug reactions such as drowsiness and dizziness, that increases the risk of falls, driving impairment, visual impairment, cognitive impairment, and upon discontinuation may cause paradoxical rebound insomnia, delirium, and nightmares all of which exacerbate the initial insomnia. All of the negative aspects of sleeping aid use are exaggerated for older, frail adults. Some patients experience an early (young-age) onset dementia with a substantial component of insomnia. Due to the many risks associated with traditional sleeping aids they are often inappropriate in adults living with cognitive impairment and/or frailty.
Lemborexant comes from a new class of medications for insomnia. Lemborexant is a dual orexin receptor antagonist that blocks the binding of wake-promoting neuropeptides orexin A and orexin B to their receptors orexin 1 receptor (OX1R) and orexin 2 receptor (OX2R), which is thought to suppress wake drive. Unlike other sleeping aids, lemborexant has not shown to be significantly associated with driving impairment, rebound insomnia, or dependence/withdrawal symptoms. Also, in clinical trials it only rarely causes the types of adverse events associated with benzodiazepines and other traditional sedatives and is less often associated with discontinuations due to adverse events. While lemborexant is available on the Canadian market it is unclear how this medication will be tolerated by patients living with dementia. Understanding the effectiveness, tolerability, and safety of lemborexant will be helpful in an N of 1 trial to understand the details of effect and effectiveness in individual patients living with dementia and insomnia.

Succinylcholine is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker. It can produce rapid and reliable intubating conditions. However, it can cause myofibrillation in some patients, which can lead to cardiac arrest. Rocuronium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker. It can be used to prevent myofibrillation caused by succinylcholine. The purpose of this study is to determine the median effective dose of rocuronium for the prevention of myofibrillation caused by succinylcholine.
The study was conducted in a university hospital. 120 patients aged 18-80 years old who were scheduled for elective surgery under general anesthesia were enrolled in the study. Patients were randomly divided into three groups according to age: 18-44 years old, 45-59 years old, and 60-80 years old. The initial dose of rocuronium for pre-injection was set at 0.04mg/kg according to previous literature and preliminary test results. The dose of rocuronium was according to the patients' myofibrillation level. If there is no myofibrillation (negative reaction), the dose of rocuronium in the next patient will be reduced until the patient has myofibrillation. If there is myofibrillation (positive reaction), the dose of rocuronium will be increased in the next patient until the patient is no fibrillation. The median effective dose of rocuronium was calculated by the up-and-down method.

Therasphere® is a new treatment for liver cancer and liver tumors. It is a type of radiation therapy. It uses tiny glass beads that are filled with radioactive material. The beads block the blood flow to the tumor and release radiation that destroys the tumor.

Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a chronic relapsing brain disease characterized by impaired control over alcohol consumption, preoccupation with alcohol, and continued use despite harm. AUD is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In Denmark, 10-15% of the population suffers from AUD at some point in their lives.
Alcoholic liver disease (ALD) is a spectrum of liver diseases ranging from fatty liver, alcoholic hepatitis, and cirrhosis. ALD is the most common cause of liver disease in Denmark and the leading cause of liver transplantation.
The prevalence of ALD in patients with AUD is high. In a Danish study, 30% of patients with AUD had fatty liver and 10% had cirrhosis.
The natural course of ALD ranges from full recovery to death. The prognosis is poor in patients with cirrhosis, with a 20-year mortality of 50-60%.
The treatment of ALD is based on abstinence from alcohol. However, only 20-30% of patients with AUD achieve long-term abstinence.
The diagnosis of ALD is based on clinical examination, blood tests, and imaging. However, ALD is often diagnosed at an advanced stage.
The aim of the Liver Care Trial is to investigate whether screening for ALD in patients with AUD improves the prognosis.
The Liver Care Trial is a randomized controlled trial. Patients with AUD are randomized 1:1 to either screening for ALD or no screening.
Screening for ALD is done by a liver stiffness measurement (Transient Elastography) and blood sampling.
The primary outcome is alcohol abstinence or light consumption (≤ 10 units/week) the last 30 days 6 months after randomization.
The secondary outcomes are:
Heavy drinking days last 30 days
Change in AUDIT-C score (yes or no) since randomization
The hypothesis is that screening for ALD in patients with AUD improves the prognosis.

A hemorrhagic stroke follows the rupture of a weakened blood vessel in the brain causing accumulation of blood and compression of the surrounding brain tissue. An ischemic stroke follows a blocked blood vessel by a thrombus (blood clot) or embolism. In both types of strokes, the specific region of the brain supplied by the affected blood vessel is deprived of oxygenated blood, causing local hypoxia that damages the brain tissue and cells. Both types of stroke are very serious, however ischemic stroke is more common. Neuronal cell death is followed by plasma membrane disruption, swelling of organelles, leaking of cell contents into extracellular space, and loss of neuronal function. Therapeutic management of ACIS is a multidisciplinary approach with a primary goal of revascularization and limiting neuronal injury.

Immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI) are a new class of cancer therapy that have revolutionized the treatment of many cancers. They work by blocking proteins called immune checkpoints, which are proteins that can act as a brake on the immune system. Blocking these proteins allows the immune system to attack cancer cells more effectively. However, while ICI can be very effective at treating cancer, they can also cause side effects, some of which can be serious or even life-threatening. One of the most common side effects of ICI is inflammation of the joints, known as immune-related arthritis (irAA).

Patients who have developed irAA while receiving ICI therapy for cancer.

The primary treatment for OA knee conservatively is physiotherapy which includes strength training, modalities, knee bracing, resistance training and Kinesiotaping.
Resistance exercise can reduce knee pain severity and leg strength in participants with symptomatic knee OA. Exercise interventions using free weights or machines have generally focused on movements with concentric muscle contractions.
Kinesiotape (KT), is an elastic woven-cotton strip with a heat- sensitive acrylic adhesive structure.
The aim of this study is to compare the effect of quadriceps strengthening and kinesiotaping on gait parameters in patients with knee osteoarthritis.

The symptoms are varied and can be physical, psychological or cognitive. The prevalence of Long COVID is estimated at 10 to 30% of the population infected with SARS-CoV-2. The symptoms of Long COVID can be disabling and have a significant impact on the quality of life of patients. There is currently no effective treatment for Long COVID.
The respiratory symptoms of Long COVID are very common and can be severe. They are often accompanied by a decrease in the capacity of the respiratory muscles and a dysfunction of the respiratory control.
The Cardiac coherence (CC) is a breathing control technique that has been shown to improve respiratory muscle capacity and respiratory control. It is a simple technique that can be learned quickly and easily.
The objective of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a respiratory training to CC on the reduction in the symptomatology of patients with Long COVID.
The study will be a randomized controlled trial. The patients will be divided into two groups: an intervention group and a control group. The intervention group will benefit from a complementary respiratory training to CC during 6 months in addition to the usual care procedure. The control group will follow a usual care procedure in the event of Long COVID.
The primary endpoint will be the reduction in the symptomatology of patients with Long COVID. The secondary endpoints will be the decrease of overall symptoms over time, the decrease of specifics symptoms (fatigue, dyspnoea, anxiety and depression, cognitive disorders, Post Traumatic Stress Disorder), and the impact of the disease on daily life.
The study will be conducted at the Reunion University Hospital. The duration of participation for each patient will be 6 months.

Oral anticoagulation (OAC) is the most effective treatment for preventing AF-related strokes, but it is underused. Guidelines recommend that all patients with AF should have their stroke risk assessed using a clinical prediction rule, and that OAC should be offered to all patients at high risk. However, population-based studies show that many patients at high risk are not receiving OAC, and many patients at low risk are receiving it. This suggests that many patients are not receiving care that is consistent with current guidelines.
Patient decision aids are tools that can help patients make informed decisions about their care. The investigators have developed a web-based decision aid for patients with AF who are considering OAC to prevent stroke. The tool allows patients to estimate their risk of stroke and bleeding, and to compare the benefits and harms of different OACs. The tool also allows patients to identify their personal preferences for stroke prevention, and to see how these preferences match with the different OACs. The tool then summarizes the patient's risk and preferences in a report that can be shared with their doctor.
The investigators are now conducting a pilot study to evaluate the impact of this decision aid on the process of shared decision-making for stroke prevention in patients with AF. The investigators will compare patients who use the decision aid with patients who do not. The investigators will measure the impact of the decision aid on patient knowledge, decision quality, and the concordance between patient preferences and their selected stroke prevention therapy. Respiratory failure is a common problem in the intensive care unit (ICU). It is defined as an inability of the respiratory system to provide adequate gas exchange to the tissues. It is classified into two types: hypoxemic respiratory failure (type 1) and hypercapnic respiratory failure (type 2). Type 2 respiratory failure is characterized by hypoventilation and retention of carbon dioxide (CO2). It is often caused by a failure of the central nervous system to drive ventilation, a decrease in the compliance of the respiratory system, or a combination of both.
Non-invasive ventilation (NIV) and high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy (HFNC) are two methods of non-invasive respiratory support that are commonly used in patients with acute respiratory failure. NIV is delivered through a mask that covers the nose and mouth. It works by applying positive pressure to the airways during inspiration, which helps to open the lungs and improve breathing. HFNC delivers warm and humidified oxygen through prongs that fit into the nostrils. It provides a high flow of oxygen, which helps to open the airways and improve breathing.
The aim of this study is to compare the efficiency of HFNC and NIV in patients with acute moderate hypercapnic respiratory failure. The study will be conducted in the ICU of Kasr El Ainy hospital. The study will include 100 patients who will be randomly assigned to receive either HFNC or NIV. The study will last for 2 years.
The primary outcome of the study will be the failure of treatment modality. The secondary outcomes will be mortality, ICU stay, length of mechanical ventilation, and the number of complications.
The study will help to determine the efficiency of HFNC in patients with acute moderate hypercapnic respiratory failure. It will also help to determine the rate of complications associated with HFNC and NIV.

The treatment of Kienbock's disease is controversial. In early stages, conservative treatments such as immobilization, anti-inflammatory drugs, and activity modification may be effective. Frostbite injury has been a significant cause of morbidity and mortality for as long as humans have experienced cold winters. When frostbite occurs, there are two primary mechanisms through which tissue damage occurs, though the main mechanism focused on here is systemic cooling. Frostbite is a multiphase process that starts with systemic cooling. As the body cools, blood is shunted from the extremities to the core to maintain heat in the vital organs. During this shunting, there is extensive vasospasm in the extremities and the tissue becomes ischemic. Upon further cooling, tissue ice crystals form within the cells and interstitial spaces causing desiccation and cell destruction. This occurs in the soft tissues and also affects the endothelium of the micro- and macro-vasculature. Clots form in the microvasculature, worsening the ischemia. All ischemic tissues release pro-inflammatory factors, which increase inflammation and worsen clotting. Upon rewarming of the frozen tissues, the reperfusion can worsen the inflammatory state as these factors released by the ischemic tissue are now able to circulate. Rapid rewarming is used as a tool to mitigate this reperfusion injury, but it does not eliminate the damage. After rapid rewarming, the tissue is assessed for the extent of damage to determine next treatment steps. Diagnosis varies by institution, but the main goal of all diagnostic modalities is to determine if there is a vascular cutoff causing tissue ischemia. At Regions Hospital, the main diagnostic method that has been used for over 20 years is conventional angiography. This clearly demonstrates the microvasculature of the tissues and allows the intra-arterial catheter directed sheaths to be placed to start thrombolytics, heparin, and vasodilators to treat the tissue ischemia. Other diagnostic modalities used elsewhere include Technetium 99 triple phase bone scans, SPECT imaging, and indocyanine green (ICG) microangiography. It is characterized by being unilateral, frontotemporal, pulsatile, of moderate or severe intensity, nausea and/or vomiting, sensitivity to movement, visual, auditory, and other afferent stimuli may appear. The lumbar plexus block (BPLE) is a regional anesthesia technique used for lower limb surgeries. It is performed at the level of the lumbar plexus, which is located in the retro-muscular plane of the psoas major muscle. The BPLE can be performed blindly or with ultrasound guidance. The ultrasound guidance allows a better precision and a lower number of side effects. The lumbar plexus is located at the level of the anterior aspect of the vertebral bodies, between the psoas major muscle and the posterior aspect of the quadratus lumborum muscle. The ultrasound transducer must be placed in a parasagittal plane, perpendicular to the vertebral bodies. The lumbar plexus appears as a hyperechoic structure, surrounded by the hypoechoic psoas major muscle. The lumbar plexus is located at a depth of 3 to 6 cm. The ultrasound-guided BPLE can be performed using two different techniques: the trident technique and the shamrock technique. The trident technique consists in placing the transducer in the parasagittal plane, at the level of the iliac crest. The lumbar plexus appears as a hyperechoic structure, surrounded by the hypoechoic psoas major muscle. The lumbar plexus is located at a depth of 3 to 6 cm. The shamrock technique consists in placing the transducer in the parasagittal plane, at the level of the anterior superior iliac spine. The lumbar plexus appears as a hyperechoic structure, surrounded by the hypoechoic psoas major muscle. The lumbar plexus is located at a depth of 3 to 6 cm. The shamrock technique is more often used than the trident technique. However, the trident technique has the advantage of allowing a better visualization of the lumbar plexus. The aim of this study is to compare the trident technique and the shamrock technique, in order to determine which technique should be favored for the ultrasound-guided BPLE.

The incidence of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) in men significantly increases with age and is estimated to impact over 80% of men 70 to 80 years of age. HoLEP is one of many treatments for BPH and associated lower urinary tract symptoms. Compared to other minimally invasive surgical techniques for treatment of BPH, HoLEP has been found to have superior outcomes and is a prostate size-independent procedure with excellent durability, high efficacy, and low complications rates. However, transient stress urinary incontinence (SUI) following HoLEP may last for several months after surgery and can lead to diminished patient quality of life during the recovery period. Measures to prevent or reduce post-operative SUI following HoLEP, including pelvic floor physical therapy (PFPT), may improve patient outcomes. SUI is also commonly documented after radical prostatectomy (RP) for prostate cancer. The mechanism for incontinence in both RP and HoLEP is thought to at least partially be related to temporary weakness of the external urinary sphincter, which is part of the pelvic floor musculature. While it is unclear if post-operative PFPT alone reduces SUI for patients who have undergone RP, there is evidence that PFPT started pre-operatively and continued post-operatively can decrease SUI following RP. The utilization of pre-operative PFPT for patients undergoing HoLEP to reduce SUI is currently not well documented. To date, only one study has demonstrated evidence that PFPT prior to HoLEP may improve continence at 3 months. However, the study included patients with a BMI significantly lower than average in the United States, utilized an unclear PFPT program, and had a relatively small median prostate size ( 60 mL), which is important as studies have shown that prostate size can affect post-operative incontinence. We propose a prospective randomized trial to investigate the efficacy of standardized pre-operative PFPT in reducing SUI and improving patient QoL following HoLEP. This study will help determine the role of pre-operative PFPT in the management of HoLEP associated SUI.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the gastrointestinal tract, and surgery is the preferred treatment method for primary resectable GIST. The guidelines recommend that patients at high risk of recurrence should be treated with tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKI) such as imatinib for at least 3 years after surgery. However, in actual clinical practice, some patients face the situation of early withdrawal or prolonged medication, so the timing of drug withdrawal needs to be further studied. Recent studies have reported that some GIST patients who have achieved disease control through long-term use of imatinib can still achieve a long progression-free survival after drug withdrawal, and those who relapse after drug withdrawal can still achieve disease control after re-use of imatinib. This suggests that for some selected patients, a drug holiday treatment mode could be possible, in which drugs are discontinued when appropriate and restarted if necessary. How to select patients suitable for this mode of treatment needs further exploration. Liquid biopsy of peripheral blood circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) to detect minimal residual disease (MRD) can be used for the diagnosis, efficacy evaluation, recurrence and drug resistance monitoring of a variety of malignant tumors. Existing studies have explored the drug holiday treatment mode based on MRD detection assisting patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer to use TKI. Therefore, this one-arm prospective observational clinical study will assist some high-risk GIST patients who have been treated with imatinib for 3 years after surgery and have achieved disease control to adopt the treatment mode of drug holiday based on MRD detection, aiming to evaluate the value of MRD detection in monitoring postoperative recurrence of high-risk GIST, investigate the effect of drug holiday treatment mode based on MRD detection on disease recurrence and patient survival, and to explore whether it can delay the occurrence of drug-resistant mutations.

Cardiac surgery is the most important treatment for serious coronary heart disease, valvular heart disease, congenital heart disease and other heart diseases. Its postoperative mortality and serious complications have also been widely concerned, especially in patients with pulmonary hypertension. The persistent pulmonary hypertension and systemic vascular paralysis during the perioperative period are the main causes of early postoperative death and serious complications such as organ failure.
Catecholamine vasoactive drugs commonly used in cardiac surgery may aggravate the condition of pulmonary hypertension, while the use of drugs to reduce pulmonary hypertension, such as nitric oxide, prostaglandins and phosphodiesterase inhibitors, may worsen the state of systemic vascular paralysis.
Vasopressin and oxytocin are two effective components in pituitrin, and vasopressin is the main component that exerts strong vasoconstrictive effect.
Vasopressin binds to receptors distributed in vascular smooth muscle, pituitary and kidney, and exerts its effects by regulating adenosine triphosphate sensitive K+ channel function, nitric oxide production and enhancing vascular response to catecholamine.
In addition, oxytocin can also bind to the receptors distributed in the heart and vascular endothelium, and play a role by releasing atrial natriuretic peptide and nitric oxide.
Therefore, pituitrin can not only constrict systemic circulation vessels and increase systemic circulation pressure, reduce pulmonary artery pressure and pulmonary vascular resistance, but also protect the heart and kidney.
Therefore, this study intends to explore whether pituitrin has an impact on the prognosis of patients with pulmonary hypertension after cardiac surgery, so as to provide reference for its clinical application.

In our clinical experience, patients and families would prefer NiPPV initiation in the home environment but this is not standard of care. This proposal will evaluate the feasibility and safety of an innovative model of care for NiPPV initiation in the home environment utilizing remote telemonitoring compared to usual care which is in-hospital polysomnography (PSG) laboratory-based initiation. The incidence of CMC requiring NiPPV is exponentially growing. NiPPV effectively corrects abnormal gas exchange, improves sleep quality, and reduces symptoms of chronic respiratory failure. The use of NiPPV has been associated with increased survival and improved health-related quality of life (HRQOL). To ensure effectiveness, NiPPV must be used for all periods of sleep and settings must be individually-titrated. Unfortunately, poor adherence results in many CMC being undertreated for chronic respiratory failure. Successful NiPPV initiation is critical because early negative experiences are commonly reported barriers to adherence and early usage predicts longer term use. Standard of care is the initiation and titration of NiPPV during a one-night in-hospital PSG. A PSG is challenging for CMC and families due to their medical fragility and lasting effects of travel and a disrupted routine, the significant amount of equipment and supplies that must be brought to the study as well as the financial implications and additional psychosocial stress for caregivers. In addition, negative experiences with NiPPV may be exacerbated by introduction of the therapy in an unfamiliar PSG laboratory with burdensome monitoring. Furthermore, a one-night PSG provides limited sleep data that may not be representative of dynamic and variable sleeping patterns that occur in the comfort of one's home. Recent technological advances in remote NiPPV monitoring coupled with a shift to virtual care models has enabled a patient and family centered opportunity to bypass the PSG laboratory and initiate NiPPV at home. Remote NiPPV monitoring extends data collection beyond discrete health care encounters and provides real-time data on adherence and efficacy that can be wirelessly transmitted to facilitate setting adjustment by clinicians. Background:
Radioactive iodine therapy is a common treatment for thyroid cancer. It is given as a pill and is absorbed by the thyroid gland. It is also absorbed by other tissues in the body, including the lacrimal gland (tear gland). The radiation from the radioactive iodine can damage the lacrimal gland and cause blockage of the tear duct. This is called nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO). Symptoms of NLDO include tearing, discharge, and redness of the eye.
Artificial tears are a common treatment for dry eyes. They are eye drops that mimic the natural tears of the eye. They are used to lubricate the eye and reduce irritation.
Researchers want to see if artificial tears can prevent NLDO in people who are treated with radioactive iodine for thyroid cancer.
Objective:
To see if artificial tears can prevent NLDO in people who are treated with radioactive iodine for thyroid cancer.
Eligibility:
People ages 18 and older who are treated with radioactive iodine for thyroid cancer
Design:
Participants will be screened with a physical exam and medical history.
Participants will be put into 1 of 2 groups by chance.
Group 1 will receive artificial tears. They will be given a bottle of artificial tears and will be told to use them as directed. They will be told to use the drops every 15 minutes for 2 hours, then every 30 minutes for at least 4 hours or until bedtime on the day of the radioactive iodine treatment. They will be told to use the drops once every hour for 12 hours on the day after the treatment. They will be told to use the drops 4 times on the second day after the treatment. They will be told to use the drops 2 times on the third day after the treatment. They will be told to use the drops once in the morning and once in the evening on the fourth day after the treatment.
Group 2 will not receive artificial tears.
All participants will have a follow-up visit 2 weeks after the radioactive iodine treatment. At this visit, they will have an eye exam to see if they have NLDO.

New or worsening high blood pressure in pregnancy can develop into a disease called preeclampsia. If left untreated, preeclampsia may turn into eclampsia. Eclampsia occurs when a pregnant person has a seizure or a stroke, which can lead to lifelong health problems, or even death. In 2018, 14% of pregnant people who gave birth in North Carolina experienced high blood pressure. Rural, low-income, and women of color are at greatest risk for complications of high blood pressure in pregnancy and postpartum. These same individuals also face challenges in accessing care. To improve maternal health outcomes for these patients, the Alliance for Innovation on Maternal Safety (AIM) developed the Severe Hypertension During Pregnancy and Postpartum Period Safety Bundle (HTN bundle) which includes five areas of focus: (1) Readiness of clinics to change practices (2) Recognition of high blood pressure (3) Response to patients with high blood pressure during pregnancy or postpartum; 4) Reporting/Systems Learning to track data related to clinic changes and (5) Respectful Care to ensure equity and respect in care of patients.
The ACHIEVE (Advancing Community and Clinical Care for Childbirth-related Hypertension through Implementation, Engagement, and Valuing Equity) Initiative was developed to support outpatient clinics in providing more effective care to pregnant individuals with high blood pressure. Adapting this bundle for community clinics providing pregnancy care has the potential to reach more birthing people outside the hospital setting who are most vulnerable to complications.
In the initial phase of ACHIEVE, the study team partnered with three rural Piedmont Health Services (PHS) clinics that serve mostly White and Latinx patients. Text-messaging health interventions are considered an effective, scalable way to deliver behavioral health interventions, and they have been used as evidence-based solutions in primary care settings among older adults for behaviors other than alcohol use to supplement traditional care. Contrary to stereotypes, older adults use mobile technology, seek online and mobile interventions, and often engage longer compared to younger populations. The primary objective of the proposed study is to evaluate effectiveness of scalable, tailored text- messaging programs for alcohol use among older adults. This study focuses on gain and loss framing of behavior change goals (i.e., the positives of change and the negatives of remaining with the status quo), critical components of behavioral science and health behavioral interventions. Loss-framing is used to motivate individuals to avoid future problems by focusing on the consequences of no change in behavior, and gain-framing is used to facilitate progress by focusing on the benefits of change. The investigators will design and evaluate three text-messaging programs using a randomized controlled trial: (A) Loss-framed messaging (B) Gain-framed messaging; and (C) Combined (loss and gain) messaging among a sample of 150 older adults with hazardous drinking. Participants will be randomized to one of the three conditions, each of which will last 8 weeks. Participants will undergo cross- sectional online assessments (baseline, week 4, week 8 and week 16), and they will also complete a mobile assessment (via text message) once per week to track drinking. Finally, the investigators will explore how the effects condition are impacted by gender and age (via moderation analysis).

Older adults with MS present with poor health status and functioning, cognitive and ambulatory difficulty, dependence for activities of daily living, and reduced physical activity participation. The common approach for managing MS involves disease-modifying drugs, yet this first-line approach for medical management has little efficacy in older MS age groups (i.e., those 50+ years of age). Exercise training has been recognized as a promising approach for maintaining and/or restoring physical and cognitive health in older adults from the general population and younger adults with MS. To date, there is a dearth of research examining the benefits of exercise training among older adults with MS. The current study proposes a remotely-delivered exercise training program for improving cognition and mobility among older adults with MS. The proposed research adopts an innovative intervention approach (via telerehabilitation) with rigorous design for evaluating the feasibility and efficacy of a home-based exercise intervention program in older adults with MS who have cognitive and walking impairment. This exercise training program adopts an innovative intervention approach via telerehabilitation and is convenient and accessible for older adults with MS. This research may have practical relevance for improving physical activity among older adults with MS through alleviating travel concerns and reducing environmental/social barriers. If successful, the proposed project will provide foundations for implementing larger, high-quality RCTs using remotely-delivered exercise intervention for managing the consequences of aging and MS and ultimately contributing to successful aging with MS.

Chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) is a common disease of the nose and sinuses. It is characterized by symptoms of nasal blockage, nasal discharge, loss of smell, and facial pain or pressure. It is a chronic disease that can last for months or even years. The disease can affect quality of life and cause significant economic burden.
The mainstay of treatment for CRS is medical therapy and functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS). However, medical therapy is not effective for all patients and recurrence after surgery is common. To address these issues, a novel bioabsorbable steroid-releasing stent has been developed. The stent is designed to be implanted in the sinus cavity after FESS to provide sustained release of steroids to the sinus mucosa. The stent is made of a biodegradable material and will be absorbed by the body over time.
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of the bioabsorbable steroid-releasing stent for the treatment of CRS. The study will be a randomized controlled trial. Patients with CRS who are scheduled to undergo FESS will be randomly assigned to receive either the bioabsorbable steroid-releasing stent or a conventional non-stenting procedure. The primary outcome measure will be the need for postoperative interventions, medical and surgical, as determined based on review of video endoscopic findings by an independent blinded surgeon. Secondary outcome measures will include endoscopic and radiologic scores, pain scores, and implantation successful rate.
The study will be conducted at the First Affiliated Hospital of Wenzhou Medical University. A total of 100 patients will be enrolled in the study. The study will last for 1 year.

Perioperative stroke is a significant complication after surgery. Unfortunately, covert stroke occurs in one out of fourteen elderly patients after non-cardiac surgery and is associated with an increased risk of long-term cognitive decline. Further, perioperative overt stroke is associated with an 8-fold increase in perioperative mortality, prolonged length of hospital stay, and decreased quality of life. For shoulder surgery performed in the beach chair position, due to systemic hypotension and reduction in cerebral perfusion pressure, cerebral desaturation events and impaired cerebral autoregulation can occur in up to 80% of patients. Most perioperative stroke in non-cardiac surgery is ischemic and is related to brain hypoperfusion. Importantly, brain hypoperfusion is potentially modifiable with simple measures such as increasing systemic blood pressure (BP) if brain ischemia is identified early enough. However, deliberate hypertension is not devoid of risk and there is currently no effective monitor that can detect brain hypoperfusion during surgery. Cerebral oxygenation has been used clinically as a measure of adequate brain perfusion during surgery. An early clinical trial at Western found that monitoring cerebral oxygenation was associated with fewer cases of major organ dysfunction in cardiac surgery patients. Despite this promising initial finding, current commercial cerebral oximeters have a number of limitations that prevent reliable perioperative neuromonitoring, including non-specificity due to signal contamination from extracerebral tissue, especially during administration of vasoconstrictors or hypothermia. In addition, current commercial cerebral oximeters only have two channels to monitor the frontal lobe regions (i.e., anterior cerebral artery territory). This monitoring strategy assumes that cerebral oxygenation is homogenous across different brain regions so that measurements from the frontal regions can be used clinically to represent the adequacy of global brain oxygenation. Such a limited spatial coverage may result in undetected stroke, despite the patients having apparently normal cerebral oxygenation in the frontal regions throughout surgery.
