Functional tricuspid regurgitation (TR) develops due to functional and structural alterations related to heart failure (HF), mitral valve disease and atrial fibrillation. An increase in cardiac filling pressure due to left ventricular (LV) systolic or diastolic dysfunction leads to left atrial, right atrial (RA) and right ventricular (RV) remodeling, which causes tricuspid annular dilatation and TR. The development of significant functional TR causes RV dysfunction and further dilation of RV, which deteriorates TR. Functional TR may occur with HF with preserved or reduced ejection fraction (EF), and the prevalence of moderate-to-severe functional TR is around 19% in patients with HF. Regardless of LVEF or pulmonary artery pressure, presence of moderate or severe functional TR is associated with more symptoms, reduced cardiac output, and worse renal function. A vicious cycle of significant TR, RV volume overload, adverse remodeling of RA, RV, and tricuspid annulus, and consequent aggravation of TR is suggested as a pathophysiologic mechanism of the poor clinical outcomes of patients with TR, and the presence of moderate or severe functional TR is a strong independent determinant of mortality in patients with HF. Because functional TR has a strong prognostic impact and plays an important pathophysiologic role in patients with HF, functional TR is suggested as a therapeutic target in HF. However, there have been no proven medical therapies for TR and only loop diuretics are cautiously recommended for relief of congestive symptoms in patients with severe TR and signs of RV failure. In patients with functional TR associated with systolic dysfunction, medical therapy for HF with a reduced EF may diminish functional TR by improving LV systolic function. Otherwise, the morbidity and mortality of patients with functional TR remain high and a novel therapeutic agent is needed to improve clinical outcomes of HF patients with functional TR and a preserved LV ejection fraction. The investigators hypothesize that the earlier locomotor training is started, the better the outcome. The investigators will test this hypothesis by comparing the effects of early, sub-acute, and chronic locomotor training on walking ability, cardiovascular function, and motor recovery. The investigators will also determine if the effects of locomotor training are dependent on the severity of the spinal cord injury.
The investigators will recruit 160 participants with acute spinal cord injury and begin training 60 days after injury. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four groups: early training, sub-acute training, chronic training, or standard of care. The early training group will begin training within 60 days of injury, the sub-acute training group will begin training 3 months after injury, the chronic training group will begin training 6-12 months after injury, and the standard of care group will not receive any additional training. All groups will receive standard of care treatment.
All participants will undergo baseline assessments within 60 days of injury. These assessments will include walking ability, cardiovascular function, and motor recovery. Premenstrual syndrome (PMS) is a group of physical, psychological and social symptoms that occur regularly in the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle and disappear within a few days after the onset of menstruation. In this syndrome, anxiety, irritability, lack of concentration, depression, mood swings, drowsiness, sleep disturbance, breast tenderness, appetite change, bloating, headache, weight gain, abdominal pain, fatigue and gastrointestinal symptoms are observed. Since these symptoms negatively affect both the work and personal lives of women, safe and effective treatments are needed. In this case, many women report using exercise as a strategy to help them cope with PMS, and exercise is often recommended for symptom management.
PMS can also play a role in symptoms by affecting the individual's food choices. Emotional eating behavior is defined as a person's use of food as an escape from negative emotions and can lead to many conditions such as obesity, eating disorders and hormonal problems.
Health promotion means increasing one's control over one's health by improving one's own health. It enables the individual to improve their physical and social environment, change their behavior, and reach the best level of physical and mental health.
Nurses have important duties in this regard due to their roles such as health education, health protection, development and consultancy. In this study, it is thought that the training given according to the health promotion model will both create a resource for nurses and contribute to the literature with the results obtained by applying this training to people experiencing PMS.
The research will be conducted as a pretest-posttest randomized controlled study. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a major public health problem, affecting 200,000 patients in Europe each year and is associated with high mortality (30-40%). The ventilatory management of ARDS is a major issue in intensive care medicine. The ventilatory strategy should aim to maintain adequate oxygenation while limiting ventilator-induced lung injury. The ventilator settings should be adjusted according to the patient's respiratory status. In clinical practice, the respiratory status of patients with ARDS is monitored by physicians, who adjust the ventilator settings when necessary. However, in many intensive care units (ICUs), nurses are responsible for monitoring the patient's respiratory status and adjusting the ventilator settings according to a predefined protocol.
The aim of this study is to evaluate the impact of a paramedical care protocol for the ventilation of patients with ARDS on mortality and the duration of mechanical ventilation. This is a prospective, multicenter, randomized, controlled, open-label, phase III, stepped wedge cluster randomized design. This experimental design involves the sequential implementation of an intervention in the clusters included over several periods. The order in which the clusters received the intervention was determined by drawing lots; at the end of the study, all the clusters received the intervention at some point and were observed during a pre- and post-intervention control period (each cluster is its own control).
The primary endpoint will be a combination of mortality and the number of days without mechanical ventilation at D28. This composite criterion will be prioritised so that survival is given priority in the analysis over the shorter duration of mechanical ventilation.

Intramuscular injection is a common procedure in psychiatry. It is used to administer treatments to patients who are difficult to treat or who have not taken their medication. It is also used to treat acute episodes.
The Z-track and Airlock techniques are two methods of administering an injection that are supposed to reduce the risk of complications.
The Z-track technique consists of injecting the product in an angle, then drawing the needle out in the same angle, so that the product is deposited in the muscle and not under the skin. The Airlock technique consists of pushing the plunger of the syringe to the end after the injection, to prevent the product from coming back out through the needle.
The aim of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of the Z-track and Airlock techniques in reducing pain and complications related to intramuscular injection of Haloperidol decanoate.
The study will be conducted in 2 parallel groups. The experimental group will be offered an intramuscular injection using the Z-track and Airlock techniques, while the control group will have an usual injection.
The primary outcome measure is pain reduction, assessed using a millimeter-scale visual analogic scale (VAS) to measure pain perceived by the patient 5 minutes after the treatment.
The secondary outcome measures are:
The loss of active product when the needle is withdrawn
The diameter of active product that flow back through the puncture site
The impact of the injection on the occurrence of secondary complications
The patient's satisfaction with the injection technique
The therapeutic alliance between the patient and the nurse
The levers and obstacles to changing professional practice among psychiatric nurses.

The VAS score of the PENG block combined with lateral femoral cutaneous nerve block group was lower than that of the PCA pump group at rest and on movement at 24 hours, 48 hours and 72 hours after surgery. The consumption of analgesic drugs in the PENG block combined with lateral femoral cutaneous nerve block group was lower than that in the PCA pump group at 24 hours, 48 hours and 72 hours after surgery. The incidence of adverse reactions in the PENG block combined with lateral femoral cutaneous nerve block group was lower than that in the PCA pump group. In conclusion, the PENG block combined with lateral femoral cutaneous nerve block has better analgesic effect and fewer adverse reactions than the PCA pump for postoperative analgesia after hip replacement surgery.

Endometriosis is a chronic disease affecting 10 to 15% of women of reproductive age. It is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, which causes inflammation and fibrosis. The diagnosis is based on the clinical examination, associated with biological and imaging data. The latter is used to confirm the diagnosis and to evaluate the extent of the disease. The gold standard is currently the transvaginal ultrasound, but its sensitivity is limited. The MRI is a non-invasive examination that allows a global assessment of the disease. However, it does not make it possible to evaluate the mobility of the pelvic organs, which is an important criterion for the diagnosis of endometriosis.
The aim of this study is to evaluate the mobility of the pelvic organs in patients with endometriosis by adding a dynamic sequence to the MRI examination. This sequence will be performed during the routine examination. The dynamic sequence will make it possible to evaluate the mobility of the pelvic organs by pushing on the vaginal wall. The images will be analyzed by two radiologists specialized in gynecological MRI. The results will be compared with the results of the clinical examination and the ultrasound.
The hypothesis of the study is that the dynamic sequence will improve the diagnosis of endometriosis.

The second is through the skin, where light is sensed by cells that are not part of the eyes. This is called the non-visual system. Primary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis (PPMS) is a common subtype of Multiple Sclerosis (MS) that affects approximately 15% of people with MS. People with PPMS experience a steady accumulation of disability from the onset of symptoms, with no relapses or remissions. There are currently no disease-modifying therapies for PPMS. The investigators believe Remote Ischemic conditioning (RIC) is ideally suited to be tested as a therapy for progression in MS. RIC is a simple, non-invasive, and inexpensive intervention that involves inducing short periods of cyclical tissue ischemia (reversible lack of blood flow) that confers subsequent protection against ischemia-reperfusion-injury. The investigators will investigate whether RIC treatment can prevent disability worsening in people with PPMS. This is a phase II open-label, single-center, single-arm futility trial. The study will follow the Simon-2-stage MiniMax design for futility studies. The primary objective of this trial is to demonstrate non-futility of RIC for reducing progression of disability, as measured with the timed 25-foot walk (T25FW), in people with PPMS.

Tetralogy of Fallot (ToF) is the most common cyanotic congenital heart disease (CHD). The mortality rate of ToF has decreased significantly since the Blalock-Taussig shunt and the Font procedure were introduced. However, the mortality rate of ToF primary repair is still high, ranging from 5% to 10%. Therefore, it is important to identify risk factors that can predict the outcome of ToF primary repair.
Inflammation is one of the factors that can affect the outcome of cardiac surgery. Previous studies have shown that the neutrophil-lymphocyte ratio (NLR) and platelet-lymphocyte ratio (PLR) are associated with the outcome of cardiac surgery. However, the association between the absolute lymphocyte count (ALC) and the outcome of cardiac surgery has not been studied.
This study aimed to evaluate the prognostic value of NLR, PLR, and ALC in predicting the outcome of ToF primary repair. This was a retrospective observational study on ToF primary repair in National Cardiovascular Center Harapan Kita between Januari 2020 until December 2022. The preoperative data included were patients' gender, age, weight, oxygen saturation, and associated diagnosis other than ToF. The preoperative data of complete blood count and differential count must be tested from the most recent peripheral blood samples taken no later than 14 days before the surgery. The data obtained were the number of days of the most recent blood test including the leukocyte count, percentage neutrophil, percentage and absolute lymphocyte count, thrombocyte count, as well as the derived variables such as NLR ratio and thrombocyte lymphocyte ratio (TLR). The intraoperative data included were the use of cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB), CPB time, aortic cross-clamp (AOX) time, and the total duration of surgery. Patients were evaluated and followed-up for any complications and postoperative mortality during the same hospital stay until discharge. Patients were then followed up for any cause of mortality within 30 days postoperative.

Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (RRD) is a common retinal disease characterized by detachment of the neurosensory retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). It is caused by a break in the retina that allows the fluid from the vitreous cavity to pass under the retina, detaching it. The standard treatment of RRD is pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) combined with sulfur hexafluoride (SF6) gas tamponade. However, the anatomical success rate of PPV alone is lower in large retinal tears and in the presence of proliferative vitreoretinopathy (PVR). Scleral buckling (SB) is a well-established technique that has been used for many years to treat RRD. It is a procedure that involves placing a band or buckle around the eye to apply pressure to the wall of the eye and push the retina back into place. The use of SB in combination with PPV has been shown to be more effective than PPV alone in large retinal tears and in the presence of PVR. However, SB is associated with cosmetic problems such as scleral scarring and strabismus.
In this study, the investigators will compare the anatomical success rate of PPV alone with that of PPV combined with SB in the treatment of RRD. The investigators will also compare the visual outcome and the incidence of complications between the two groups. The investigators will also compare the anatomical success rate of PPV with perfluoropropane (C3F8) gas tamponade alone with that of PPV combined with SB. C3F8 gas tamponade has been shown to provide better postoperative positioning of the retina than SF6 gas tamponade.
The investigators hypothesize that the use of SB in combination with PPV will improve the anatomical success rate of RRD surgery compared to PPV alone. The investigators also hypothesize that the use of C3F8 gas tamponade in combination with PPV will improve the anatomical success rate compared to PPV alone.

Cognitive dysfunction is a core pathophysiological feature of psychosis and one of the strongest predictors of functional outcomes. Several studies indicate that current early intervention programs may not significantly alter long-term clinical outcome, suggesting that critical treatment target(s), beyond symptoms and functional status, are not being addressed. Evidence strongly indicates that, along with cognitive dysfunction, impaired motivation is also a critical target and unmet therapeutic need. The investigators have demonstrated both behavioral gains and improved neural system functioning after neuroscience-informed cognitive training in schizophrenia, in both chronic and early phases of the illness. In young recent-onset individuals (average age of 21 years), the investigators' multi-site double-blind randomized controlled trial showed that 40 hours/ 10 weeks of cognitive training delivered at home over a laptop resulted in significant gains in global cognition, verbal memory, and problem solving compared to a computer games control condition. Cognitive gains were significantly correlated with enhanced thalamic volume and thalamo-cortical connectivity, as well as increased white matter integrity. A meta-analysis of 11 RCTs in early schizophrenia has also indicated the benefit of cognitive remediation approaches. Impaired motivation is also a core feature and very strong predictor of functional outcome in early stages of psychosis. Some studies have shown positive effects in improving motivation immediately after the intervention, but treatments that induce enduring improvements in motivated behavior are scarce. Disturbances in motivated behavior reflect a range of factors, including diminished anticipatory pleasure, difficulty learning from rewarding outcomes, reduction in effort expended to obtain rewarding outcomes, and impairment and disconnection between components of social motivation. This makes it difficult to determine optimal therapeutic approaches. However, some headway is starting to appear in the literature. Prehabilitation is a relatively new and evolving concept in patient care. Prehabilitation utilises prescribed exercise in the time prior to surgery with the aim of improving a patient's functional capacity enabling them to better withstand the stress of surgery. 1-3 This is required due to the physiological insult cause by surgery, particularly in those with cancer, which in turn results in a decline in patients' function. Post-operative restorative rehabilitation programmes such as Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) are commonplace and used with the aim of returning the patients' function towards their preoperative baseline. 4 ERAS has been shown to improve postoperative outcomes, including length of stay, re-admission, and complication rates.5 However, despite this and unlike ERAS, it's use is still patchy, with no national protocols in existence.

Due to evidence demonstrating its effectiveness, the benefits of commissioning prehabilitation services have been acknowledged in several surgical fields,6-8 however there is significant heterogeneity in that which is available, for how best to approach a prehabilitation service to achieve the best results. Physical activity is a core component seen across all reported prehabilitation programmes. However, heterogeneity is seen across multimodal programmes, meaning the type of exercise, duration and supervision of physical activity is variably administered between studies. Additional interventions such as dietary support, psychological wellbeing and smoking cessation are also variably addressed in some studies.

Accurate, reliable, and reproducible assessment of cardiopulmonary fitness is required to effectively prescribe and monitor patients as they progress through a prehabilitation programme. Currently, cardiopulmonary fitness assessment requires patients to attend for in person assessment to undergo Maximal or Submaximal exercise testing.

Pilonidal disease (PND) is a common benign skin disease of the natal cleft. It is characterized by the presence of pilonidal sinus tracts and sinus cavities, which can become infected and form an abscess. The prevalence of PND is estimated to be 21-23 per 100.000 persons per year. The disease is more common in men than in women.
PND is often treated surgically. The most common surgical procedure is the excision of the pilonidal sinus and sinus tracts with primary closure of the wound. This procedure is associated with a high rate of wound complications, such as wound infections, dehiscence and the need for surgical revision.
In 2010, a new minimally invasive surgical technique was introduced, called pit-picking surgery. This technique is less invasive than the standard procedure and is associated with a lower rate of wound complications. However, the rate of recurrence of PND is still high after pit-picking surgery.
In 2015, a new laser-assisted technique was introduced, called SiLaC (Sinus Laser assisted Closure). This technique is also less invasive than the standard procedure and is associated with a lower rate of wound complications. In addition, the recurrence rate after SiLaC seems to be lower than after pit-picking surgery.
The aim of this study is to compare the success rate of pit-picking surgery with SiLaC. The success rate is defined as wound healing outcomes at 1 year, which includes the following: closure of all pits, absence of symptoms, absence of persisting sinuses and absence of recurrence of PND.
The study is a multicenter, single-blinded, randomised, controlled, superiority trial. It is conducted in 10 hospitals in the Netherlands. Patients are randomly assigned to pit-picking surgery or pit-picking surgery with SiLaC. The primary outcome is the success rate of treatment at 1 year. Secondary outcomes are the success rate of treatment at long-term follow-up, pain scores, patient reported outcome measures, wound healing and complications, work rehabilitation, return to daily activities, recurrence rate, need for secondary or revision surgery, patient satisfaction and quality

Substance use disorder (SUD) is a complex condition in which there is uncontrolled use of a substance despite its harmful consequences. People with SUD have an intense focus on using a certain substance(s) such as alcohol, tobacco, or illicit drugs, to the point where the person's ability to function in day-to-day life becomes impaired. People keep using the substance even when they know it is causing or will cause problems. Drug use brings with it the likelihood of several negative health consequences. These can include a wide range of physical and mental health disorders, foremost of which are dependence, HIV infection, hepatitis-related liver diseases, overdose and premature death. The problem of substance use is becoming one of the most serious and rapidly growing phenomena all over the world. It accounts for substantial global morbidity, mortality, and financial and social burden.
In Egypt, SUD is a serious public health threat. Recent studies have demonstrated increases in the prevalence of the use of tobacco, illegal drugs, and over-the-counter drugs, particularly among youth. Drug treatment registers are often used as a proxy indicator of treatment demand. This information is useful for analysis of service utilization and can be used as an indicator of trends in prevalence and patterns of high-risk drug consumption.
Assiut University Hospital is the biggest hospital in Upper Egypt, and it provides health services for Assiut city and most of the neighboring governorates. Addiction management unit of Assiut University Hospital contains 16 beds, based on paid service and about 400 patients have been admitted per year.
SUD is a dynamic process that changes constantly over time with new trends of drug dependence emerge every now and then, thus timely information about trends in psychoactive substance use could yield tailored interventions and reduce potential harms. Identifying personal, social, and demographic characteristics of patients with this disorder at the local, regional, and national levels helps physicians, health authorities, and policy-makers detect early emerging trends and enable them better plan and implement prevention, treatment, and rehabilitation programs.
This study aims to identify sociodemographic, personal characteristics, as well as patterns of illicit drug abuse in patients admitted for addiction treatment.

Hepatocellular carcinoma is one of the most intractable primary malignancies in the hepatobiliary and pancreatic tract with a poor overall survival worldwide. Surgery in the form of hepatectomy or liver transplantation provides the best chance of cure for early-stage disease. Unfortunately, the vast majority of hepatocellular carcinoma patients suffer from advanced unresectable or metastatic disease at diagnosis. Currently targeted therapy alone, or in combination with anti-vascular endothelial growth factor antagonist, is the standard first-line treatment for metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma. On the other hand, there is growing evidence suggesting that radiation therapy (external or internal) with or without immune checkpoint inhibitors can produce or even augment abscopal effect in which the tumours away from the radiation field also show significant tumour shrinkage. The underlying mechanism of eliciting abscopal effect includes the increased antigen presentation by the myeloid cells within the tumour stroma leading to enhanced tumour cell killing. Previous case reports showed that radiation therapy alone can induce abscopal effect in mice and human models. However, a robust and concrete evidence of abscopal effect with combinational immune checkpoint inhibitors and radioembolisation or external radiation therapy in hepatocellular carcinoma is still lacking. This phase 2 single-arm study will investigate the efficacy and safety of combination of immune checkpoint inhibitors and radioembolisation for previously untreated metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma.

The extremity artery is the peripheral blood vessel of the whole body, and it is often involved early in the diseases that are easy to damage the small vessels, such as atherosclerosis and connective tissue diseases. Early lower limb atherosclerosis mainly occurs in the dorsal foot artery, which is commonly seen in people with diabetes and long-term smoking. Connective tissue diseases such as systemic sclerosis and systemic lupus erythematosus also mainly involve small blood vessels, and vascular lesions may appear earlier than those of other specific organs such as heart and lung. Because of its shallow location, the extremity artery can be better used as a screening site for vascular diseases, and it is the window for early reaction of vascular diseases.
However, the early stage of extremity artery disease is easy to be ignored, and patients often have pain and numbness of the affected limb. When the disease is severe, it can lead to ulcer not healing, and even limb gangrene and amputation, which greatly affects the quality of life and brings huge troubles and economic pressure to the patients. Therefore, early diagnosis of extremity arterial lesions is of great significance for early diagnosis of microvascular injury diseases such as atherosclerosis and connective tissue diseases, reducing the incidence of complications, and reducing the rate of amputation and mortality.
Ultrasound is a non-invasive imaging technique widely used in clinic. In recent years, with the development of ultrasound technology, the frequency of ultrasonic probes has been increasing. Because of its higher resolution, high-frequency ultrasound can clearly display the superficial vascular structure and blood flow, detect vascular lesions early, and accurately quantify the degree of stenosis, providing a new and beneficial tool for clinical observation of the structure and blood flow of the extremities.
The purpose of this multi-center clinical study was to establish the normal value of high frequency ultrasound for the structure and blood flow of the extremities of Chinese Han adults, and to explore its influencing factors, so as to provide a quantitative reference for the early diagnosis, degree evaluation and curative effect observation of the structure and blood flow of the extremities.

The purpose of the study is to test the safety and efficacy of STERIFY GEL in promoting healing of periodontal pockets following SRP, compared with treatment with SRP alone.
With specific visco-elastic and mucoadhesive properties, STERIFY GEL easily penetrates into the deepest and hard-to-reach areas of periodontal and peri-implant pockets, adhering to the gingival tissue and alveolar bone, providing complete coverage of the pockets. The effect of STERIFY GEL is promoted by a physical mechanism of action. After SRP, the gel is applied into the gingival pocket, where it acts primarily as a filler to restore volume, physically preventing bacteria from entering and reinfecting the pocket. STERIFY GEL can thus mechanically protect treated pockets and bone defects, promoting tissue healing. The occluding action at the level of periodontal and peri-implant gingival pockets, in synergy with the accessory action of hydroxytyrosol, nisin, and magnesium ascorbyl phosphate, prevents bacterial recolonization and promotes subsequent tissue regeneration.
Although SRP surgery is considered a gold standard treatment for periodontitis, it may in some cases be insufficient to decontaminate the pocket allowing bacteria to recolonize the tissues promoting new inflammation that can worsen the clinical picture.
STERIFY GEL may find useful application in cases of moderate to severe chronic periodontal disease as an adjunctive treatment following SRP to improve and accelerate healing parameters and prevent recurrent inflammation and infection.
In addition, antimicrobial control action prevents antibiotic use and the risk associated with antibiotic resistance.
Such control of periodontal disease also allows for the maintenance of patients who cannot undergo surgical treatment (e.g., patients on bisphosphonate therapy, defected etc.).

Cardiac involvement is considered a serious condition and a frequent cause of death in patients with sarcoidosis. 18F-FDG PET/CT is currently used as part of the diagnostic criteria for cardiac sarcoidosis, but it has shown limitations in the evaluation of cardiac sarcoidosis due to the high physiological uptake of FDG in normal cardiac muscle. Elaborate preparations are required for patients including either a low-carbohydrate diet followed by long fasting or heparin loading before FDG-PET. In heparin loading, the rare adverse effect of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia should be considered. Therefore, it is of interest to find a PET/CT tracer that displays high sensitivity and specificity without requiring thorough patient preparation and minimizing any adverse effects. A potential tracer is the somatostatin-based tracer 64Cu-DOTATATE, which is routinely used for the diagnosis and monitoring of treatment response in patients with neuroendocrine tumors. Inflammatory cells, including macrophages that are found in sarcoid granulomas, express somatostatin receptors on their surface, whereas normal cardiomyocytes do not. This allows for the potential use of macrophage imaging in cardiac sarcoidosis. In the CuDOSIS trial, groups A and B (suspected and confirmed cardiac sarcoidosis, respectively) will be scanned with 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT in addition to the routinely performed 18F-FDG PET/CT. Further, to examine whether the macrophage infiltration pattern is different in patients with cardiac sarcoidosis and other inflammatory heart diseases, a group of patients with confirmed or clinically suspected myocarditis will be included (group C); this group will only be scanned with 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT. Finally, data from a group of patients with neuroendocrine tumours (negative controls) who have previously been scanned with 64Cu-DOTATATE will be included.

The investigators have developed a culturally adapted intervention for depression in older people in Nigeria, emhGAP-Age, which is a brief psychosocial intervention delivered by lay providers. To be successful, an ACL reconstruction requires a strong incorporation of the tendon to the bone within or at the margin of the tunnel, but the tunnel itself is at risk of widening, therefore compromising the tendon attachment. A composite of harvested healthy autologous bone fragments from the tunnel and autologous thrombin and fibrin, generated from the patient's own blood could be used at the interface between tunnel and ACL graft at the tibia and femur to reduce frequency of tunnel widening and therefore improve graft-bone-integration.
The study seeks primarily to determine less tibial tunnel widening when a bone/PrP-composite is applied directly in the tibial tunnel compared to the same surgery without using the composite, measured with CT and MRI. Secondary study objectives are to evaluate femoral tunnel widening, tibial and femoral graft incorporation, graft maturation and knee function (clinical, functional, patient reported) over the course of 24 months follow-up and to evaluate occurrence of procedure- and product-related adverse events and complications.
This is a prospective, single-center, single-blinded, 2-arm-parallel, randomized, controlled study with 24 months follow-up. Participants will be recruited from the Knee Surgery department at Schulthess Klinik when scheduled for ACL reconstruction. The study sample comprises 107 patients, allocated 1:1 on experimental and control arm. Outcome measures are taken at 0, 6, 12, and 24 months. The total study duration is 48 months. The study duration per patient is 24 months.

Rapid sequence induction (RSI) is a standardized method of induction of general anaesthesia in pediatric patients, in order to prevent aspiration of gastric contents. It includes the administration of an anaesthetic agent and a neuromuscular blocker, after the patient's airway is secured and the lungs are preoxygenated. Preoxygenation is a process of delivering 100% oxygen to the patient's lungs, in order to increase the oxygen reserves in the lungs and the body. It is achieved by face-mask or by non-invasive ventilation (NIV). NIV is a method of delivering oxygen and assisting ventilation through the nose or the mouth, without the need for endotracheal intubation. High flow nasal oxygenation (HFNO) is a method of NIV, in which heated and humidified oxygen is delivered through the nose at high flows (25-70 L/min), creating a positive pressure in the airways.
HFNO has been shown to be effective in preoxygenation in adults and in children over 8 years old. However, there is no data regarding the use of HFNO in preoxygenation in children under 8 years old.
The aim of this study is to compare the efficacy of HFNO in preoxygenation in children under 8 years old, to face-mask preoxygenation and to combined HFNO and face-mask preoxygenation.
The hypothesis is that HFNO is non-inferior to face-mask preoxygenation and that combined HFNO and face-mask preoxygenation is superior to face-mask preoxygenation.

Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) is the sixth most common cancer worldwide. The American Cancer Society estimates that in 2018, there will be 64,690 new cases of HNSCC in the United States and 13,710 deaths from the disease. The standard of care for patients with HNSCC is surgical resection, which often includes removal of lymph nodes from the neck (called a neck dissection). The goal of the neck dissection is to remove any cancer that may have spread to the lymph nodes.
The current standard of care for identifying lymph nodes involved by cancer is to perform a physical exam and/or an imaging study (such as a magnetic resonance imaging [MRI] scan) prior to surgery. During the surgery, a blue dye is injected near the tumor in the mouth and the surgeon looks for blue-stained lymph nodes to identify which lymph nodes should be removed. However, the blue dye does not always spread to the lymph nodes and the physical exam and imaging studies are not always accurate. As a result, some patients undergo a more extensive neck dissection than necessary, removing more lymph nodes than needed, and other patients may have cancer-containing lymph nodes left behind.
The purpose of this study is to determine if a new imaging agent called 111In-panitumumab can be used to identify lymph nodes involved by cancer prior to surgery. 111In-panitumumab is a radioactive form of a drug called panitumumab, which is approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for the treatment of HNSCC. The investigators will give the drug as an injection into a vein 1-5 days before surgery. The investigators will then use a special camera to detect the drug in the lymph nodes. The investigators will compare the results of the 111In-panitumumab scan to the results of the physical exam and imaging studies that are currently used to identify lymph nodes involved by cancer. The main clinical manifestations are excessive anxiety and worry, which are difficult to control, and patients often worry about various things such as health, family, work, and finances. The disorder can cause significant impairment in social, occupational, and other important areas of life.
The pathogenesis of GAD is not clear. It is currently believed that it may be related to abnormalities in the function of the amygdala, hippocampus, and prefrontal cortex.
The treatment of GAD mainly includes psychotherapy and drug therapy. However, the effect of psychotherapy is limited, and the recurrence rate is high after drug therapy is stopped. Therefore, it is of great significance to explore new treatment methods for GAD.
The vagus nerve is the tenth cranial nerve, which is the longest nerve in the autonomic nervous system. It is widely distributed in the body and plays an important role in regulating the function of various organs. In recent years, studies have found that stimulating the vagus nerve can reduce anxiety symptoms.
Transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation (tVNS) is a new method of stimulating the vagus nerve. It is non-invasive and can be used at home. It is expected to become a new treatment method for GAD.
This study is a randomized, double-blind, sham-controlled, parallel-group, multicenter clinical trial. The study will be conducted in 3 hospitals in China. A total of 100 patients with GAD will be recruited. Participants will be randomly divided into a medication-combined tVNS group and a medication-combined sham stimulation group. Both groups will receive 4 weeks of treatment. The primary outcome is the change in the Hamilton Anxiety Scale (HAMA) score. Secondary outcomes include the change in the Hamilton Depression Scale (HAMD) score, the change in the Generalized Anxiety Scale (GAD-7) score, and the change in brain function indicators. The incidence of adverse events in each group will also be recorded.

The etiopathogenesis of lacrimal passage obstruction appears to be multifactorial. Chronic inflammation has been suggested to be the most causal. Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is a standard surgical procedure used to treat nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO), with a reported success rate of more than 90%. On the other hand, semiconductor diode laser can achieve more effective tissue dissection than direct probing technique with minimal hemorrhage and improved intraoperative view. Hence, dacryoendoscopic-assisted laser dacryoplasty with silicone intubation (DLDI) offers direct therapy to the obstructed site, leading to minimal collateral damage external to the target zone. In addition, this procedure can be performed under local anesthesia as an outpatient procedure in the office, and it has advantages such as short surgery time and less risk of bleeding during surgery, resulting in its increasingly widespread use in China. The graft is made of a biocompatible material called polyetherketone (PEEK) and is designed to be implanted in the arm. Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the 2nd leading cause of cancer death in the United States (US), with 149,500 new CRC cases, and 52,980 deaths expected in 2021. Surveillance colonoscopy after adenoma removal is recommended to reduce CRC incidence and mortality, but the benefits of surveillance are uncertain for older adults. The investigators will conduct a retrospective cohort study of 132,800 older adults with a prior normal colonoscopy vs. colonoscopy with polypectomy (n=29,548) prior to age 75. The investigators will compare cumulative CRC risk after age 75. The investigators will also conduct a case-cohort study of 270 incident and 150 fatal CRC cases, and a random sample subcohort (n=1,036) with prior polypectomy to assess comparative effectiveness of exposure vs. no exposure to surveillance colonoscopy. The investigators will conduct 44 semi-structured one-on-one qualitative interviews with VA patients (older adults) and providers (primary care, GI, geriatrics) to understand perspectives on CRC risk, and potential benefits and harms of surveillance (Aim 3a). The investigators will then convene an expert panel with key stakeholders including Veterans, primary providers, geriatricians, gastroenterologists, VA leaders, and policy makers to present Aim 1, 2, and 3a findings (Aim 3b). The primary outcome will be specific recommendations regarding use of surveillance colonoscopy in older adults, ranked by priority and feasibility, that can guide VA policy around future implementation (or de-implementation) of surveillance among older adults.

Papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) is the most common endocrine malignancy and the incidence has increased rapidly in recent years. Although the majority of patients with PTC have an excellent prognosis, recurrence and persistence of the disease remain a challenge. The cervical lymph nodes are the most common site of recurrence. The risk of lymph node metastasis is related to the tumor size, extrathyroidal extension, and lymph-vascular invasion. The risk of lymph node metastasis is low in patients with small PTC without extrathyroidal extension and lymph-vascular invasion. The current guidelines recommend that the central compartment (level VI) should be routinely dissected in patients with PTC with clinically detectable lymph nodes (cN1). However, there is no consensus on the management of the central compartment in patients with cN0 disease. Some surgeons perform prophylactic central neck dissection (PCND) in patients with cN0 disease, while others do not. The aim of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of PCND in cN0 patients with low-risk PTC.
This is a prospective, open-label, multicenter, randomized controlled phase III study. Patients with cN0 low-risk PTC will be randomly assigned to the PCND group or the non-PCND group. The primary endpoint is the excellent response rate of the central compartment. The secondary endpoints are the recurrence-free survival (RFS) and the disease-free survival (DFS).

The aim of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a brief behavioral teacher training for teachers of children with behavioral difficulties at school. The training is based on behavioral principles and consists of two (bi)weekly training sessions of two hours and a third session of one hour in which the training will be evaluated and maintenance training will be provided. The training is individualized and focuses on the four most problematic behavioral difficulties of the child in the classroom, as selected by the teacher. The training will be provided by trained mental health professionals. The effectiveness of the training will be evaluated by comparing the change in the severity of the four selected behavioral difficulties in specific classroom situations between the training group and a control group that receives practice as usual only. The investigators expect that the training will also improve the teacher-student relationship, the teacher's sense of self-efficacy, and the frequency of supportive teacher behavior. Chronic non-specific neck pain is a common health problem. It is defined as neck pain without a known cause. It is often accompanied by pain in the upper limbs and/or the head. This pain can be disabling and have a significant impact on quality of life.
The aim of this study is to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and usability of a tele-rehabilitation combining immersive virtual reality exercises and therapeutic education for people with chronic non-specific neck pain.
The intervention will last 6 weeks and will consist of 5 virtual reality sessions (15-20 minutes per session, without supervision of the physiotherapist) and 1 teleconsultation session per week. In addition, participants will receive several brochures to read on their own (therapeutic education). These brochures will be discussed with the physiotherapist during the teleconsultations.
The primary objectives of this study are to evaluate the feasibility of the intervention (retention rate, adhesion to treatment, safety, implementation at home, online consultations), the acceptability of the intervention (satisfaction), and the usability of the virtual reality system and the online consultations.
The secondary objectives are to evaluate the effects of the intervention on cervical range of motion, neck disability, pain intensity, kinesiophobia, illness perception, and the global perceived effect.
The investigators will also investigate the experiences of the participants with the intervention and the virtual reality system.
The investigators hypothesize that the intervention will be feasible, acceptable, and usable, and that it will have positive effects on the secondary outcome measures.

Cerebral palsy (CP) is a non-progressive lesion of the central nervous system that occurs in early stages of development. It is the most common physical disability in childhood. Children with CP have motor impairments that limit their ability to perform activities of daily living.
Hand-Arm Bimanual Intensive Therapy including Lower Extremities (HABIT-ILE) is an intensive therapy that continuously incorporates postural control and LE function. This motor learning-based approach include specificity of the practice, motivation, shaping of the task, intensive blocks of training and Hands-Off. Moreover, the therapy is goal-oriented to increase functional independence during daily living.
HABIT-ILE is an intensive therapy that requires a lot of time and human resources. The COVID-19 pandemic has shown that it is possible to deliver intensive therapies at home. The aim of this study is to assess if HABIT-ILE at home is not inferior to HABIT-ILE in camp regarding physical abilities, functional activities and participation of the participants. Moreover, if the maintenance of skills during HABIT-ILE camp at 3- and 6-months post-therapy has been proven, the question of improving them has not been investigated yet. Indeed, we know that in order to maintain the skills learned during the HABIT-ILE therapy, it is necessary to practice them on a daily basis. If a skill is not used it will lead to a cortical reorganization of the motor cortex at the expense of this skill. Thus, there is a persistent cycle of decreased utilization that leads to unfavorable cortical reorganization that leads to decreased utilization, etc. It is called learned non-use.
In order to answer this question, after the two weeks of both HABIT-ILE modality, we will set up a HABIT-ILE telerehabilitation follow-up for 9 weeks. This study therefore also aims to assess if the patient's abilities could be potentialize with a follow-up than without a follow-up after two weeks of HABIT-ILE therapy.

Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM) is the most common cause of preterm birth before 34 weeks gestation. It is associated with significant maternal and neonatal morbidity and mortality. There is no standard of care for the management of PPROM. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) recommends that cervical dilatation and effacement be assessed at least weekly in symptomatic patients. This is typically done with a speculum exam. However, there is concern that speculum exams may cause ascending infection and lead to maternal chorioamnionitis and preterm birth. Digital exams are an alternative method of cervical evaluation. There is no data comparing digital exams to speculum exams in patients with PPROM. The investigators hypothesize that digital exams are non-inferior to speculum exams in patients with PPROM. The primary outcome will be pregnancy latency. Secondary outcomes will include maternal and neonatal morbidity and mortality.

Liver transplantation is currently the most effective treatment for selected patients with liver cancer. However, the shortage of donor livers is the main factor limiting the development of liver transplantation. The incidence of liver cancer in China is the highest in the world, and the number of liver transplantation patients is increasing year by year. The Milan criteria and its variants have strict requirements for tumor size and number, and many patients with liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (cHCC) cannot meet the criteria, and cannot obtain the opportunity of liver transplantation. In 2015, Norwegian scholars proposed a new surgical method, that is, resection and partial liver segment 2-3 transplantation with delayed total hepatectomy (RAPID) . This approach allows transplantation of the left liver (segments 2+3) to an adult recipient, while the remaining enlarged right hemi-liver is transplanted to another adult recipient, effectively avoiding some unsuitable left lateral lobe livers for pediatric recipients to be wasted. Recipients who received right-hemi-liver transplantation had a similar prognosis compared with those who received whole-liver transplantation. Therefore, if the RAPID technique is confirmed to be feasible, it can greatly alleviate the shortage of liver donors. In addition to cadaver sources, living adult donors can also be considered as the source of liver donors. A smaller left lateral lobe donor liver also places less burden on the donor than a left or right hemiliver. To sum up, our center proposed and designed a clinical study of sequential adult left lateral lobe liver transplantation (SALT) in the treatment of patients with liver cirrhosis with HCC based on clinical surgical experience. On the basis of RAPID surgery, the overall survival rate of patients with liver cirrhosis with HCC was evaluated by SALT.

Mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection are among the most frequently performed surgeries today, and pain control is an important problem affecting patient comfort in the postoperative period in these patients. Regional techniques can be used for postoperative pain control following breast surgery. Ultrasound (US) guided serratus posterior superior block (SPSIPB) is a new interfacial plane block defined by Tulgar et al in 2023. It is based on injection on the serratus posterior superior muscle at the level of the 2nd or 3rd rib. This block provides analgesia in conditions such as interscapular pain, chronic myofascial pain syndromes, scapulocostal syndrome, and shoulder pain. The SPS muscle is located at the C7-T2 level. It attaches to the lateral edges of the second and fifth ribs. It is innervated by the lower cervical and upper intercostal nerves. With the SPS block, these nerves are blocked and analgesia is provided. In the cadaveric study of Tulgar et al., it was determined that the spread of serratus posterior superior interfacial plane block; 7-10 intercostal levels on the left side only in the superficial fascia of the trapezius muscle. Spread dye was observed at intercostal levels, absent on the right. There was prominent staining on both the surface and skin of the rhomboid major, while the rhomboid minor was only stained in the skin. SPSP block will provide successful analgesia in procedures involving the thoracic region such as chronic myofascial pain, breast surgery, thoracic surgery, and shoulder surgery. In this study, our aim is to investigate the efficacy of US-guided SPSIPB for postoperative analgesia management after mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection surgery. Hemorrhoidectomy is a procedure to remove hemorrhoids. It is done when other treatments, such as lifestyle changes and medications, have not worked.
After hemorrhoidectomy, pain is the most common complaint. Many procedures have been described to decrease the pain. These include internal sphincterotomy (cutting of the internal sphincter muscle) and injecting botulinum toxin into the internal sphincter.
Botulinum toxin is a poison produced by a type of bacteria called Clostridium botulinum. It is used in small doses to treat certain medical conditions. It works by blocking nerve signals that cause muscle contraction.

The study will also look at how long it takes for people to return to their normal activities after each type of surgery.
The study will be done at the University of Michigan Health System. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups.
Group 1 will have hemorrhoidectomy alone.
Group 2 will have hemorrhoidectomy and internal sphincterotomy.
Group 3 will have hemorrhoidectomy and botulinum toxin injected into the internal sphincter.

Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) is a syndrome characterized by recurrent abdominal pain accompanied by abdominal discomfort, changes in bowel habits, and abdominal bloating. It is a common condition, affecting approximately 10% of the population in Korea, and its chronic gastrointestinal symptoms significantly impact patients' daily life and quality of life. Factors such as changes in the intestinal microbiota and the intestinal ecosystem are crucial in its etiology. Modern individuals, who are often exposed to numerous stressors, frequently experience persistent intestinal hypersensitivity and inflammation. Foods that are not well digested and fermented in the intestines, producing a significant amount of gas - such as those rich in seasonings, dairy products, caffeine, and alcohol - are known to trigger symptoms. Therefore, it is suggested that a controlled environment like a Temple Stay, which provides both dietary regulation and stress control, could lead to meaningful symptom improvement. However, there is currently a lack of objective scientific research on this. This might control chronic intestinal inflammation and hypersensitivity, leading to subjective symptom improvement and enhanced treatment satisfaction for patients. The recent global pandemic has highlighted the need for health and wellness interventions that are freely accessible from a person's home; likewise, studies have shown that citizens with lifestyle related diseases are more vulnerable to infections such as COVID-19. The goal therefore is to provide accessible, expert-led motivational support to Irish citizens who need help in the community in relation to promoting healthy lifestyle and preventing lifestyle-related diseases. This pilot study is a continuation of the previously approved 'RCSI Coach Connect project' that examined the impact of a similar online coach-led app on frontline healthcare workers. Lessons from RCSI Coach Connect have shown us that intelligent assistance is required to help human coaches scale this online health solution to larger citizen groups. This project will involve a close collaboration between existing partners: the RCSI Centre for Positive Psychology and Health and Empeal in the development and implementation of a coach-led digital support platform augmented by an Intelligent Coaching Assistant (ICA) for 6-months. This digital health platform is a motivational support unit only and is not intended for use or replacement of medical or therapeutic. ICA-augmented coaching has the potential to transform the coaching profession. Having ICA as a partner can facilitate human coaches to improve the quality of their work and has the potential to increase accessibility and availability of coaching through lower costs. The ICA of this digital health platform has been developed to take time-consuming administrative tasks from the human coach so that their time can be maximised for scalability. Administrative tasks that ICA have taken include, on-boarding participants, prompting participants to complete assessments and book coaching session, reporting assessment results, and gathering data for the coach (i.e. short, medium and long-term goals and targets, trackability of goals, along with their readiness to change and feelings of achievability and reality towards goals). All data gathered by the ICA is to be utilised by coaches to augment the one-to-one coaching experience between participants and coaches. Data is the lifeblood of ICA and must be protected and managed. The ICA will only gather data provided by the participants, and this data is completely voluntary. By collaborating with Empeal, the investigators will analyse this real-world data and apply it to the development and validation of an ICA-augmented coaching framework. Project Overview Res

Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is a common preventable and treatable disease that is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Dyspnea, fatigue and sleep disorders are among the most common complaints of patients with COPD. Progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) and deep breathing exercises (DBE) are used in the treatment of many physical and psychological problems. The aim of this study is to investigate the effect of PMR and DBE on dyspnea, fatigue and sleep quality in patients with COPD. The study was designed as a randomized controlled clinical trial. The sample of the study consisted of 60 patients with COPD who applied to the outpatient clinic of Bartın Training and Research Hospital. The patients were divided into three groups as PMR, DBE and control groups. The PMR exercise, which includes the systematic relaxation of the main muscle groups of the body aimed at physical and psychological relaxation, was applied twice a day, every weekday, for eight weeks. PMR exercises and training on the application of these exercises were given to the patients individually by face-to-face interview method. Deep Breath exercises training was given to the patients in this group individually by face-to-face interview. During the application, the importance of deep and comfortable breathing was explained and correct breathing technique was taught. Informing and application training took an average of 20-25 minutes for each patient. The patients were told to do the 10-minute application at home 3 times a day for 8 weeks. They were called once a week and asked whether they continued the practice and whether they had any difficulties during the exercises. Data were collected using the COPD and Asthma Fatigue Scale, Dyspnea-12 Scale and Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index. Data were analyzed using the SPSS 22.0 program.

Coronary artery disease (CAD) is the most common type of heart disease in the world. It is the leading cause of death in both men and women. The most common symptom of CAD is angina, which is chest pain or discomfort caused by reduced blood flow to the heart muscle.
In patients with angina, coronary angiography is performed to evaluate the presence and severity of CAD. Coronary angiography is an x-ray test that uses dye to visualize the arteries of the heart. If the angiography shows that the arteries are narrowed, the doctor will decide whether to perform a procedure called percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). PCI is a procedure in which a small mesh tube called a stent is placed in the narrowed artery to open it up and improve blood flow.
Before performing PCI, the doctor will want to know how much the artery is narrowed and how much the blood flow is reduced. This information can be obtained by performing fractional flow reserve (FFR) and intravascular ultrasound (IVUS). FFR is a pressure wire that is placed in the artery to measure the pressure difference across the narrowed area. IVUS is a catheter with an ultrasound tip that is placed in the artery to obtain images of the artery wall.
Ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR) is a new technique that can be used to measure blood flow. It uses an ultrasound catheter that is placed in the artery. The catheter emits ultrasound waves that can measure the speed of the blood. The UFR is calculated from the blood speed and the diameter of the artery.
The purpose of this study is to compare the accuracy of UFR to FFR and IVUS in patients with angina who are candidates for PCI. The investigators will also compare the UFR to the FFR and IVUS in predicting the need for PCI in the future.

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effect of Balint group on burnout and self-efficacy of nurse leaders in China. A randomized controlled trial was conducted in a university-affiliated hospital in China. A total of 100 nurse leaders were randomly assigned to the Balint group or the non-Balint group. The Balint group completed Balint training for a period of three months. The non-Balint group was not involved in any intervention. The primary outcome was burnout, which was measured by the Maslach Burnout Inventory-Human Services Survey (MBI-HSS). The secondary outcome was self-efficacy, which was measured by the General Self-Efficacy Scale (GSES). Data were collected at baseline and 3 months later. The independent t-test was used to compare the differences in burnout and self-efficacy between the two groups. The paired t-test was used to compare the differences in burnout and self-efficacy within the two groups. The results showed that the Balint group had lower burnout and higher self-efficacy than the non-Balint group (all p<0.05). The Balint group also had lower burnout and higher self-efficacy than at baseline (all p<0.05). The non-Balint group had higher burnout and lower self-efficacy than at baseline (all p<0.05). The results suggest that Balint group can effectively reduce burnout and improve self-efficacy of nurse leaders in China.

Long COVID is a complex and heterogeneous condition that affects multiple systems of the body. The symptoms of Long COVID are diverse and can persist for months or even years after the acute phase of COVID-19. Cognitive impairment is one of the most common and disabling symptoms of Long COVID. The prevalence of cognitive impairment in Long COVID is estimated to be 20-80%. The cognitive impairment in Long COVID is characterized by impairments in attention, memory, executive function, and processing speed. The pathophysiology of cognitive impairment in Long COVID is not well understood. The mechanisms may include direct neuro-invasion of SARS-CoV-2, autoimmune reactions, neuro-inflammation, oxidative stress, and endothelial dysfunction. There is currently no effective treatment for cognitive impairment in Long COVID. The aim of this study is to test the efficacy of acupuncture and TCM-based lifestyle management in improving cognitive impairment in people with Long COVID symptoms. This is a randomized controlled trial. The participants will be randomly assigned to one of the following four groups: (1) acupuncture, (2) TCM-based lifestyle management, (3) acupuncture + TCM-based lifestyle management, and (4) wait-list control. The treatment duration is 8 weeks. The primary outcome is global cognitive function. The secondary outcomes include cardiopulmonary function, fatigue, health-related quality-of-life, psychological distress, and neurocognitive functions. The neurobiological outcomes include IL-6, TNF-α, and cortisol. The data will be analyzed using the intention-to-treat principle. The results of this study will provide important evidence for the treatment of cognitive impairment in Long COVID.

Chronic pain has long been known as one of the major health concerns, impacting psychological health, functioning, and quality of life. However, its treatment is complex and is challenged by a complex interplay between biological, psychological, and social factors. Common pain treatments present significant medical and technological limitations, reflected in unspecific drug usage and an extremely high number of medical examinations that patients face regularly, with a huge cost burden on the healthcare system. Furthermore, the overall efficacy of pain management is often limited (73% dissatisfaction with treatment), leaving the patient in poor life conditions. Designing individualized targeted therapies requires understanding each subject's multidimensional pain experience, taking into consideration both the physical and emotional aspects involved. However, today, the golden standard measurement for pain is self-reports, which inherently suffer from subjective differences in perception and reporting. Healthcare systems advocate for the discovery of biomarkers and reliable clinical trial endpoints for pain to foster diagnosis, monitor pain progression, assess new treatments, and personalized therapeutic response. Nevertheless, most of the evidence today comes from inpatient settings or controlled laboratory environments. The pAIn-sense study aims at providing a radically novel approach in the monitoring and treatment of pain patients: a novel telemonitoring system allowing to understand the real nature of the pain (emotional vs physical), leveraging the use of advanced Artificial Intelligence techniques and wearable sensing technology collecting biometric data, therefore enabling efficient personalized treatments. To achieve this goal, the investigators will combine real patient data both from a physical and emotional perspective, to characterize the pain nature of patients and provide a tailored continuum-of-care. The system will include: Robotic wearable sensors (Hardware): wearable technology for physiological monitoring (e.g., skin conductance, blood volume pressure and heart rate, activity) Digital platform (Software): a customized application that collects psychological assessments, psychological status, medication, subjective pain level and sleep quality. AI-based engine: advanced AI models take all the previous physical and psychological information and model it to provide an outline of what is the nature of the pain level of the subject. The system will be used to monitor the patient during normal activities (day and night) while collecting physiological, psychosocial, and pain information.

Osteoarthritis (OA) is the most common form of arthritis. It is a progressive disease, which is characterized by joint pain, stiffness and loss of function. The knee is the most commonly affected joint. The current diagnostic imaging method for OA is the weight-bearing (WB) anteroposterior (AP) radiograph. This radiograph is not very sensitive for detecting early OA and is not very accurate in determining the severity of OA. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a very sensitive imaging method for detecting early OA. However, conventional MRI is performed in a non-weight-bearing and non-flexed position, which is not representative of the patient's complaints. A new MRI scanner has been developed that allows weight-bearing and flexion. The aim of this study is to investigate the value of weight-bearing MRI in the diagnosis of knee OA.
Patients with symptomatic knee OA will be included in this study. They will undergo an MRI scan of the knee in four different positions: non-weight-bearing and non-flexed, non-weight-bearing and flexed, weight-bearing and non-flexed and weight-bearing and flexed. The MRI scans will be evaluated by two experienced radiologists. The joint space width will be measured in the medial and lateral compartments. The results of the MRI scans will be compared with the results of the conventional weight-bearing AP radiograph.
The investigators hypothesize that the weight-bearing MRI is more accurate in determining the severity of knee OA than the conventional weight-bearing AP radiograph.

Dysphagia, or disordered swallowing, is prevalent in almost all neurodegenerative conditions and results in the inability to effectively protect the lower airways from foreign (i.e., food/liquid) and endogenous (i.e., saliva) material. An unfortunate consequence of dysphagia is aspiration pneumonia, which is a leading cause of death in Parkinson's disease (PD). Swallowing therapy has proven to be effective for the management of dysphagic symptoms in PD. Treatment is most often delivered in clinics once/week over short time periods with the expectation that exercises be completed at-home. However, these paradigms lack biofeedback to assess the accuracy and strength of the prescribed exercise and accountability to ensure completion of the exercise program. Without biofeedback or options for long-term therapeutic intervention at-home, patients often regress to baseline levels. The proposed research project seeks to test the effectiveness of a novel at-home surface electromyography (sEMG) biofeedback therapy tool called Biofeedback in Strength and Skill Training (BiSSKit) on swallowing safety and efficiency in patients with PD. The significance of this project lies in the fact that dysphagia is expensive in terms of patient quality of life, health outcomes, and healthcare costs. Thus, a targeted swallowing therapy system with biofeedback that can be utilized at-home may reduce hospitalizations secondary to dysphagia, help maintain therapeutic gains, and reduce the burden that dysphagia places on our healthcare system.

The goal of this study is to develop a new treatment for PLP. The treatment will be based on the idea that PLP is caused by changes in the brain after amputation. The investigators will use a technique called operant conditioning to strengthen the brain's response to sensory input from the amputated limb.
Operant conditioning is a type of learning in which a person's behavior is influenced by the consequences of that behavior. In this study, the investigators will use operant conditioning to strengthen the brain's response to sensory input from the amputated limb. The investigators will do this by providing visual feedback about the brain's response to sensory input. The investigators believe that this will lead to long-term changes in the brain, and will reduce PLP.
The investigators will test this treatment in a group of people with PLP. Central venous catheterization is a common procedure in the intensive care unit. It is used to monitor central venous pressure (CVP), administer drugs, and provide total parenteral nutrition. The internal jugular vein and subclavian vein are the two most common sites for central venous catheterization. However, in some cases, the internal jugular vein and subclavian vein cannot be catheterized due to anatomical factors or previous operations. In these cases, the axillary vein can be used as an alternative site for central venous catheterization.
The axillary vein is located in the axilla, which is the space between the upper limb and the chest wall. It is connected to the subclavian vein and then to the superior vena cava. The axillary vein is usually used for central venous catheterization in the emergency department or in the field. However, with the development of ultrasound technology, ultrasound-guided axillary vein catheterization has been widely used in the intensive care unit.
Ultrasound-guided axillary vein catheterization has many advantages. First, ultrasound can provide real-time imaging of the axillary vein and surrounding structures, which can help the operator to avoid injury to the axillary artery and other structures. Second, ultrasound can help the operator to locate the axillary vein and reduce the number of punctures. Third, ultrasound can help the operator to confirm the position of the catheter tip after catheterization.
In this study, the investigators retrospectively analyzed the data of trauma patients who underwent ultrasound-guided axillary vein catheterization in the intensive care unit. The investigators analyzed the accuracy of the catheter tip position, the incidence of complications, and the clinical outcomes of these patients. The investigators also compared the results with those of internal jugular vein catheterization and subclavian vein catheterization. The investigators hope to provide reference for the clinical application of ultrasound-guided axillary vein catheterization in trauma patients.

CAR T cell therapy is a type of treatment in which a person's T cells (a type of immune system cell) are changed in a lab so they will attack cancer cells. The cells are removed from the person's blood, changed in the lab, and then given back to the person.
Cevostamab is a monoclonal antibody that attaches to a protein called CD22 that is found on some B-cell cancers, including multiple myeloma. It is thought that cevostamab may help the immune system kill cancer cells.
This study will look at the safety and effectiveness of cevostamab in treating RRMM. It will also look at how cevostamab affects the immune system.
Cevostamab will be given as an infusion into a vein. It will be given once every 3 weeks, starting roughly 10 weeks (day 70 +/- 4 days) post-CAR T cell infusion. Myeloma responses will be assessed every cycle, and a repeat bone marrow aspirate and biopsy (BMbx) is performed at the start of cycle 8. If participants are not in an MRD-negative CR at this timepoint (or if the BM bx is inevaluable/indeterminate for CR or MRD testing), they continue with another 8 cycles of cevostamab. Worldwide more than approximately 500 million people suffer from AR (30% of the Dutch population) and its prevalence is expanding. This study is relevant as in addition to the high global occurrence of AR, this disorder has substantial effects on the quality of life (QOL) (e.g. during sleep and work). AR is related to high direct medical costs (mainly prescription of medications and outpatient visits) and indirect economic costs (including productivity decrease).
Current medications are undesirable due to their side-effects (such as sedation in the case of intranasal antihistamines (INAH)). Acupuncture for AR in general can be considered as safe and can be seen as a potential remedial blueprint for nasal congestion. The ANCAR trial aims to evaluate the effects of an acupuncture treatment protocol for nasal congestion in AR compare to azelastine nasal spray (Carelastin®). A standard treatment protocol with a fixed set of acupuncture points has been established - to be as scientific as possible from Western medical viewpoint - and this selection of acupuncture points can be seen as a solid and profound approach from which every AR patient may benefit. This standard set opens the nose and affects the underlying energetic imbalance and immunity at the same time to maintain its nose opening effect (i.e. to prevent recurrence of the complaint). The positive effects of this treatment protocol (such as improvement QOL) may result in more confidence in the direct, post-treatment and long-term effects of acupuncture and lead to more acceptance of acupuncture as a solid treatment option for nasal congestion in AR instead of using an INAH spray.

Neuroendocrine tumours (NET) are rare tumours of the digestive tract. They can be benign or malignant. When they are malignant, they can be operated on, but often they are not operable anymore and can only be treated with medication.
The first-line treatment for these patients is a somatostatin analogue (SSA). SSAs are hormone therapies that mimic the action of the hormone somatostatin. Somatostatin is a naturally occurring hormone that regulates the release of other hormones.
SSAs are very effective in controlling the symptoms of NET. However, they have no effect on tumour growth.
When the tumour starts to grow again, patients are usually offered a second-line treatment with either everolimus, sunitinib or peptide receptor radionuclide therapy (PRRT).
The SAUNA trial investigates whether continuing SSA treatment after progression is as good as stopping SSA treatment and starting a second-line treatment.
The SAUNA trial is a randomised, open-label, multicentre, phase III trial. Patients will be randomly assigned to one of the two treatment groups:
Continuing SSA treatment after progression
Stopping SSA treatment and starting a second-line treatment
The primary objective of the trial is to compare the progression-free survival of both treatment groups.
The secondary objectives are:
To compare the time to deterioration of both treatment groups
To compare the overall survival of both treatment groups
To compare the response rates of both treatment groups
To compare the quality of life of both treatment groups
To compare the safety of both treatment groups
To perform a health technology assessment (HTA) analysis
The trial will be conducted in 20 hospitals in the Netherlands.
The trial will include 180 patients. Patients will be followed for 18 months after start of second-line treatment.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a degenerative disease process that disrupts the transmission of nerve impulses, resulting in a range of neurological signs and symptoms. Walking-related impairment is one of the most common symptoms, reported to affect more than 90% of people with MS. The leading non-pharmacological intervention for walking-related deficits in people with MS is rehabilitation, such as physical therapy. The leading pharmacological intervention for walking-related deficits in people with MS is dalfampridine. Dalfampridine improves motor function by increasing nerve conduction through demyelinated axons, however, dalfampridine alone is not likely to generate neuroplastic changes needed for lasting benefits, because neural plasticity requires salient and task-specific practice with high repetition at adequate intensity, as well as complex environments that stimulate opportunities for movement to facilitate synthesis of neurotrophic factors. Indeed, the treatment effects of dalfampridine are reversed as soon as the treatment was discontinued. However, it is possible that improved nerve conduction velocity provided by dalfampridine may accelerate neuroplasticity generated from rehabilitation. Yet, combining dalfampridine with concurrent rehabilitation has never been studied. The objective of the proposed study is to test our central hypothesis that providing a motor-relearning physical therapy intervention in combination with dalfampridine will produce superior gains to either intervention alone in mobility through augmented neuroplasticity. Aim 1 will determine if dalfampridine can augment the effects of physical therapy in restoring function in people with MS by comparing the combined intervention to physical therapy without dalfampridine. Aim 2 will explore the comparative effectiveness between the combined intervention with dalfampridine alone, and between physical therapy alone and dalfampridine alone. In Aim 3, the investigators will investigate mechanisms of treatment effects by evaluating functional connectivity before and after each intervention arm.
